docs.title: Basics
docs.text: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style HTML elements — controlling their layout, color, spacing, fonts, and more.

docs.title: 1. CSS Syntax
docs.text:
selector {
  property: value;
}

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
p {
  color: blue;
  font-size: 16px;
}

docs.title: Output:
docs.text:
p {
  color: blue;
  font-size: 16px;
}

docs.title: 2. Adding CSS to HTML
docs.text: There are 3 ways to apply CSS:

docs.title: a) Inline CSS
docs.text: <p style="color: red;">Inline styled paragraph</p>

docs.title: b) Internal CSS (within <style> tag)
docs.text:
<head>
  <style>
    h1 {
      text-align: center;
      color: green;
    }
  </style>
</head>

docs.title: c) External CSS (best practice)
docs.text:
Inside <head> in index.html

<link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">

And in styles.css:

body {
  background-color: #f0f0f0;
}

docs.title: 3. Comments in CSS
docs.text: /* This is a CSS comment */

docs.title: 4. Colors in CSS
docs.text:
You can use:

  • Named colors (red, blue, green)
  • Hex codes (#ff0000)
  • RGB (rgb(255, 0, 0))
  • HSL (hsl(0, 100%, 50%))
body {
  background-color: #121212;
  color: rgb(255, 255, 255);
}

docs.title: 5. Inheritance & Specificity
docs.text:
• Some CSS properties (like color, font-family) are inherited by default
  • Specificity decides which rule wins if multiple styles apply
  • Inline > ID > Class > Element selector
<style>
  #heading { color: red; }
  .title { color: blue; }
  h1 { color: green; }
</style>

<h1 id="heading" class="title">Hello</h1>

Output color: Red (#heading wins)

docs.title: Selectors
docs.text: CSS selectors target HTML elements to apply styles. They determine what gets styled.

docs.title: a) Element Selector
docs.text:
Targets all elements of a specific type.

p {
  color: black;
}

docs.title: b) Class Selector
docs.text:
Targets elements with a specific class.

.title {
  font-weight: bold;
}

docs.title: c) ID Selector
docs.text:
Targets a unique element with a specific id.

#main-heading {
  font-size: 32px;
}

docs.title: 2. Grouping Selectors
docs.text:
Apply the same style to multiple selectors.

h1, h2, h3 {
  font-family: Arial;
}

docs.title: a) Descendant Selector
docs.text:
Targets elements nested inside another.

div p {
  color: gray;
}

docs.title: b) Child Selector (>)
docs.text:
Targets direct children only.

ul > li {
  list-style: none;
}

docs.title: c) Adjacent Sibling (+)
docs.text:
Targets the first element immediately after another.

h1 + p {
  margin-top: 0;
}

docs.title: d) General Sibling (~)
docs.text:
Targets all siblings after the first.

h1 ~ p {
  color: blue;
}

docs.title: 4. Attribute Selectors
docs.text:
Target elements based on attributes.

input[type="text"] {
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
}

docs.title: 5. Pseudo-classes
docs.text:
Target elements based on state or position.

a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

li:first-child {
  font-weight: bold;
}

docs.title: 6. Pseudo-elements
docs.text:
Style parts of elements.

p::first-line {
  font-variant: small-caps;
}

docs.title: Fonts
docs.text: Fonts control the appearance of text — including typeface, size, weight, spacing, and more.

docs.title: 1. Font Family
docs.text:
Set the typeface using font-family. Always include a fallback.

body {
  font-family: 'Arial', 'Helvetica', sans-serif;
}

docs.title: 2. Font Size
docs.text:
Controls the size of the text.

p {
  font-size: 16px;
}

docs.title: Common units:
docs.text:
• px — absolute (pixels)
  • em — relative to parent
  • rem — relative to root (html)
  • % — relative to parent
h1 {
  font-size: 2em;  /* 2x the parent size */
}

docs.title: 3. Font Weight
docs.text:
Controls thickness of text.

strong {
  font-weight: bold; /* or numeric: 100 to 900 */
}

docs.title: 4. Font Style
docs.text:
Used for italics and oblique styles.

em {
  font-style: italic;
}

docs.title: 5. Font Variant
docs.text:
Used for small-caps.

p {
  font-variant: small-caps;
}

docs.title: 6. Line Height
docs.text:
Controls vertical spacing between lines of text.

p {
  line-height: 1.6;
}

docs.title: 7. Shorthand Property
docs.text:
Combine multiple font properties.

p {
  font: italic small-caps bold 16px/1.5 'Georgia', serif;
}

docs.title: 8. Web Fonts
docs.text: Import custom fonts using @font-face or via Google Fonts:

docs.title: Example (Google Fonts):
docs.text:
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

body {
  font-family: 'Roboto', sans-serif;
}

docs.title: Text
docs.text: CSS provides properties to style and align text content in HTML elements.

docs.title: 1. Text Color
docs.text:
p {
  color: #333;
}

docs.title: 2. Text Alignment
docs.text:
h1 {
  text-align: center;
}

Values:

  • left (default)
  • right
  • center
  • justify

docs.title: 3. Text Decoration
docs.text:
Used for underlines, overlines, strikethroughs.

a {
  text-decoration: none;
}

Common values:

  • none
  • underline
  • overline
  • line-through

docs.title: 4. Text Transform
docs.text:
Controls capitalization.

h2 {
  text-transform: uppercase;
}

Options:

  • none
  • capitalize
  • uppercase
  • lowercase

docs.title: 5. Letter Spacing
docs.text:
Space between letters.

p {
  letter-spacing: 1px;
}

docs.title: 6. Word Spacing
docs.text:
Space between words.

p {
  word-spacing: 5px;
}

docs.title: 7. Line Height
docs.text:
Controls spacing between lines.

p {
  line-height: 1.5;
}

docs.title: 8. Text Shadow
docs.text:
Adds shadow to text.

h1 {
  text-shadow: 2px 2px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.3);
}

Syntax: x-offset y-offset blur-radius color

docs.title: Colors
docs.text: CSS allows you to style elements with different colors for text, backgrounds, borders, and more.

docs.title: Text Color
docs.text:
p {
  color: red;
}

docs.title: Background Color
docs.text:
div {
  background-color: #f0f0f0;
}

docs.title: Border Color
docs.text:
input {
  border: 1px solid #333;
}

docs.title: a) Named Colors
docs.text:
Predefined color names.

h1 {
  color: blue;
}

docs.title: b) Hexadecimal
docs.text:
p {
  color: #ff0000; /* red */
}

docs.title: c) RGB
docs.text:
div {
  background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);
}

docs.title: d) RGBA (with transparency)
docs.text:
div {
  background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
}

docs.title: e) HSL
docs.text:
Hue, Saturation, Lightness.

h2 {
  color: hsl(240, 100%, 50%);
}

docs.title: f) HSLA (with alpha)
docs.text:
section {
  background-color: hsla(120, 100%, 50%, 0.3);
}

docs.title: 3. Transparent Keyword
docs.text:
div {
  background-color: transparent;
}

docs.title: Specificity & Cascade
docs.text: When multiple CSS rules target the same element, the cascade and specificity determine which rule wins.

docs.title: 1. The Cascade
docs.text:
CSS applies rules based on:

  1. Source order (last rule wins if equal specificity)
  2. Importance (!important)
  3. Specificity
  4. Origin (browser default < user styles < author styles)

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
p {
  color: blue;
}

p {
  color: red;
}

Result: Red (red overrides blue because it comes later)

docs.title: 2. Specificity
docs.text:
Each selector has a specificity value:

Selector Type Specificity Value Inline styles 1000 ID selectors 100 Class/attr/pseudo-class 10 Element/pseudo-element 1

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
/* Specificity: 1 */
p {
  color: green;
}

/* Specificity: 10 */
.text {
  color: blue;
}

/* Specificity: 100 */
#main {
  color: red;
}

Result: Red wins due to higher specificity.

docs.title: 3. !important
docs.text:
Overrides all specificity rules (except other !important rules with higher specificity).

p {
  color: blue !important;
}

Use sparingly – it's hard to override and often a sign of poor structure.

docs.title: 4. Specificity Comparison
docs.text: Selector Specificity h1 1 .title 10 #header 100 style="..." 1000 !important ∞ (kind of)

docs.title: Sizing Units
docs.text: CSS sizing units define dimensions like width, height, padding, margin, and font-size. They fall into two main categories: absolute and relative units.

docs.title: 1. Absolute Units
docs.text:
These do not scale with screen size or context — they remain fixed.

Unit Name Description px Pixels Most commonly used; screen-relative pt Points 1pt = 1/72 inch (used in print) cm Centimeters Physical measurement mm Millimeters Physical measurement in Inches 1in = 96px (standard)

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
.box {
  width: 200px;
  font-size: 12pt;
}

Use when: you want precise control (e.g. fixed UI components), but avoid for responsive designs.

docs.title: 2. Relative Units
docs.text: These scale based on parent elements, root, or viewport.

docs.title: a) % — Percentage
docs.text:
Relative to the parent element's size.

div {
  width: 50%; /* 50% of parent */
}

docs.title: b) em — Relative to Parent Font Size
docs.text:
1 em = font-size of the current element’s parent.

/* If parent has 16px font size */
p {
  font-size: 2em; /* 32px */
}

Stacking ems can cause unintended scaling (compound effect).

docs.title: c) rem — Relative to Root Element
docs.text:
1 rem = font-size of the html element.

html {
  font-size: 16px;
}

h1 {
  font-size: 2rem; /* 32px */
}

Preferred over em for consistent, predictable sizing.

docs.title: d) vw, vh, vmin, vmax — Viewport Units
3. calc() — Dynamic Calculations
docs.text:
Combines units for flexible sizing.

.container {
  width: calc(100% - 60px);
  height: calc(50vh + 100px);
}

Useful for subtracting fixed elements like headers or sidebars.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use rem for font sizes (scales with user settings).
  • Use px or % for borders, paddings, depending on layout needs.
  • Use vw, vh for responsive layouts.
  • Avoid absolute units like cm, pt in screen designs.

docs.title: Display Property
docs.text: The display property defines how an element is rendered in the document flow — block, inline, grid, flex, etc.

docs.title: a) block
docs.text:
• Takes up the full width
  • Starts on a new line
div {
  display: block;
}

Examples: <div>, <p>, <h1> (default block elements)

docs.title: b) inline
docs.text:
• Takes up only as much width as needed
  • Flows inline with text
  • Cannot set width/height
span {
  display: inline;
}

Examples: <span>, <a>, <strong> (default inline elements)

docs.title: c) inline-block
docs.text:
• Behaves like inline (flows with text)
  • Allows width/height to be set
button {
  display: inline-block;
  width: 100px;
  height: 40px;
}

docs.title: d) none
docs.text:
• Completely hides the element
  • Removes it from layout and DOM flow
p {
  display: none;
}

docs.title: a) flex
docs.text:
Enables flexbox layout for flexible, one-dimensional layouts.

.container {
  display: flex;
}

Use with properties like justify-content, align-items, etc.

docs.title: b) grid
docs.text:
Enables CSS grid layout — two-dimensional control.

.container {
  display: grid;
}

Use with grid-template-columns, grid-gap, etc.

docs.title: c) inline-flex / inline-grid
docs.text:
Same as flex/grid, but behaves like inline.

span {
  display: inline-flex;
}

docs.title: table, table-row, table-cell, etc.
docs.text:
Mimic HTML table behaviors.

div {
  display: table;
}

docs.title: 4. Default Values by Tag
docs.text: Tag Default display <div> block <span> inline <img> inline-block <table> table

docs.title: 5. Visual Summary
docs.text: Display New Line Width/Height Allowed Layout Control block ✅ ✅ ❌ inline ❌ ❌ ❌ inline-block ❌ ✅ ❌ flex ✅ ✅ ✅ (1D) grid ✅ ✅ ✅ (2D)

docs.title: Overflow
docs.text: The overflow property controls what happens when content exceeds the size of its container.

docs.title: a) visible (default)
docs.text:
Content spills out of the box — no clipping.

.box {
  overflow: visible;
}

docs.title: b) hidden
docs.text:
Extra content is cut off and not visible.

.box {
  overflow: hidden;
}

Used when you want a clean container without scroll.

docs.title: c) scroll
docs.text:
Adds scrollbars (always visible), regardless of need.

.box {
  overflow: scroll;
}

Bad UX if scrolling isn’t needed — use auto instead.

docs.title: d) auto
docs.text:
Adds scrollbars only if needed.

.box {
  overflow: auto;
}

Best for responsive and accessible designs.

docs.title: 2. Overflow Axes
docs.text:
You can control each axis individually:

.box {
  overflow-x: auto;
  overflow-y: hidden;
}

docs.title: Example 1: Truncate Text
docs.text:
.truncate {
  white-space: nowrap;
  overflow: hidden;
  text-overflow: ellipsis;
}

docs.title: Example 2: Scrollable Container
docs.text:
.scroll-area {
  height: 200px;
  overflow-y: auto;
}

docs.title: 4. Notes
docs.text:
• Overflow only works on block-level or positioned elements with a defined size (height or width).
  • For inline elements, overflow has no effect unless converted with display: block or similar.

docs.title: Position
docs.text: The position property defines how an element is placed in the document — static, relative, absolute, fixed, or sticky.

docs.title: 1. static (default)
docs.text:
• Normal document flow
  • top, left, right, bottom have no effect
div {
  position: static;
}

docs.title: 2. relative
docs.text:
• Positioned relative to its normal position
  • Leaves original space in the flow
.box {
  position: relative;
  top: 10px;
  left: 20px;
}

Used to nudge elements or create a reference for absolutely positioned children.

docs.title: 3. absolute
docs.text:
• Removed from document flow
  • Positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor
  • If none, it uses the html (viewport)
.child {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  right: 0;
}

Requires parent to be relative, absolute, or fixed if you want local positioning.

docs.title: 4. fixed
docs.text:
• Removed from flow
  • Positioned relative to the viewport
  • Stays in place when scrolling
.header {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

Used for navbars, back-to-top buttons, etc.

docs.title: 5. sticky
docs.text:
• Acts like relative until a threshold is reached, then becomes fixed
  • Requires a top/left/right/bottom value
.menu {
  position: sticky;
  top: 0;
}

Parent must have height for sticky to work properly.

docs.title: 6. Z-Index
docs.text:
Use z-index to control stacking order (higher = on top).

.box {
  position: absolute;
  z-index: 10;
}

Only works on positioned elements (not static).

docs.title: Summary Table
docs.text: Position In Flow Offset Allowed Scrolls with Page Reference Point static ✅ ❌ ✅ Normal document flow relative ✅ ✅ ✅ Own original position absolute ❌ ✅ ❌ Nearest positioned ancestor fixed ❌ ✅ ❌ Viewport sticky ✅/❌ ✅ ✅/❌ Toggles: self → viewport

docs.title: Variables
docs.text: CSS Variables (also called custom properties) allow you to store values in reusable, scoped variables using the -- syntax.

docs.title: 1. Declaring a Variable
docs.text:
Defined inside a selector (commonly :root for global scope):

:root {
  --main-color: #3498db;
  --padding-base: 1rem;
}

docs.title: 2. Using a Variable
docs.text:
Use the var() function:

button {
  background-color: var(--main-color);
  padding: var(--padding-base);
}

docs.title: 3. Fallback Value
docs.text:
Use a default if the variable is undefined:

p {
  color: var(--text-color, black);
}

docs.title: 4. Scope
docs.text:
Variables are scoped to the selector they are declared in:

.container {
  --local-color: red;
}

.child {
  color: var(--local-color); /* works only if .child is inside .container */
}

docs.title: 5. Dynamic Theming
docs.text:
CSS variables can be updated dynamically (e.g. in dark mode):

:root {
  --bg-color: white;
  --text-color: black;
}

.dark-mode {
  --bg-color: #121212;
  --text-color: #f0f0f0;
}

body {
  background: var(--bg-color);
  color: var(--text-color);
}

docs.title: 6. Inside Media Queries
docs.text:
Variables can be redefined based on screen size:

:root {
  --font-size: 16px;
}

@media (min-width: 768px) {
  :root {
    --font-size: 18px;
  }
}

body {
  font-size: var(--font-size);
}

docs.title: 7. Invalid Use Cases
docs.text:
CSS variables do not work in:

  • Media query expressions
  • Selectors
  • Keyframe names
  • @import paths
/* ❌ INVALID */
@media (min-width: var(--breakpoint)) { ... }

docs.title: Media Queries
docs.text: Media queries let you apply CSS based on screen/device properties, enabling responsive design.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
@media media-type and (condition) {
  /* CSS rules */
}

Example:

@media screen and (max-width: 768px) {
  body {
    font-size: 14px;
  }
}

docs.title: 2. Media Types
docs.text: Type Description all Default, applies to all devices screen Computer screens, tablets, etc. print Print previews and printers speech Screen readers

docs.title: 3. Common Features (Conditions)
docs.text: Feature Example Description max-width max-width: 600px Target screens ≤ 600px min-width min-width: 1024px Target screens ≥ 1024px max-height max-height: 500px Target short screens orientation orientation: portrait Portrait vs. landscape prefers-color-scheme dark/light Light/dark mode detection

docs.title: 4. Responsive Breakpoints (Example)
docs.text:
/* Mobile first */
body {
  font-size: 14px;
}

@media (min-width: 600px) {
  body {
    font-size: 16px;
  }
}

@media (min-width: 1024px) {
  body {
    font-size: 18px;
  }
}

docs.title: 5. Multiple Conditions
docs.text:
@media (min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1024px) {
  .box {
    background: yellow;
  }
}

Use , for OR conditions:

@media (max-width: 500px), (min-width: 1200px) {
  .header {
    display: none;
  }
}

docs.title: 6. Dark Mode Example
docs.text:
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
  body {
    background: #121212;
    color: #f0f0f0;
  }
}

docs.title: 7. Print Styles
docs.text:
@media print {
  nav, footer {
    display: none;
  }

  body {
    font-size: 12pt;
  }
}

docs.title: Float and Clear
docs.text: The float property allows elements to be taken out of normal flow and positioned to the left or right, with text/content flowing around them. clear is used to prevent wrapping around floated elements.

docs.title: 1. float Property
docs.text: Value Description left Floats the element to the left right Floats the element to the right none Default, no float

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
img {
  float: left;
  margin-right: 10px;
}

Result: The image floats to the left, and the text wraps around it on the right.

docs.title: 2. Effects of Float
docs.text:
• Floated elements are removed from normal flow
  • Parent containers may collapse if all children are floated

docs.title: 3. clear Property
docs.text:
Prevents elements from wrapping around floated siblings.

Value Description left Clears floats on the left side right Clears floats on the right side both Clears both sides none Default

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
.clearfix {
  clear: both;
}

Used to push content below floated elements.

docs.title: 4. Clearing Floats (Fixing Collapsing Parent)
docs.text: Floats can cause a container to collapse if it has no non-floated children.

docs.title: a) Using Clearfix
docs.text:
.clearfix::after {
  content: "";
  display: table;
  clear: both;
}

Apply .clearfix to the parent container.

docs.title: 5. Float vs Flex/Grid
docs.text:
Use float only for small layouts (e.g., image wrap).

Avoid it for full layouts — prefer flex or grid for proper alignment, responsiveness, and readability.

docs.title: Flexbox
docs.text: Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a 1-dimensional layout system that makes it easy to align, distribute, and order space among items in a container — either horizontally or vertically.

docs.title: 1. Enabling Flex
docs.text:
.container {
  display: flex;
}

This makes all direct children flex items.

docs.title: 2. Main vs Cross Axis
docs.text:
• Main Axis: Defined by flex-direction
  • Cross Axis: Perpendicular to the main axis
flex-direction value Main Axis Cross Axis row (default) horizontal vertical column vertical horizontal

docs.title: 3. flex-direction
docs.text:
.container {
  flex-direction: row | row-reverse | column | column-reverse;
}

docs.title: 4. justify-content (Main Axis)
docs.text:
Aligns items along the main axis.

.container {
  justify-content: flex-start | flex-end | center | space-between | space-around | space-evenly;
}

docs.title: 5. align-items (Cross Axis)
docs.text:
Aligns items along the cross axis.

.container {
  align-items: flex-start | flex-end | center | stretch | baseline;
}

docs.title: 6. align-content (Cross Axis, multiple rows)
docs.text:
Used when there are multiple lines (wrapping).

.container {
  align-content: flex-start | center | space-between;
}

docs.title: 7. flex-wrap
docs.text:
Controls whether items wrap to the next line.

.container {
  flex-wrap: nowrap | wrap | wrap-reverse;
}

docs.title: 8. Shorthand: flex-flow
docs.text:
Combines flex-direction + flex-wrap

.container {
  flex-flow: row wrap;
}

docs.title: a) order
docs.text:
Controls item visual order.

.item {
  order: 2; /* Default is 0 */
}

docs.title: b) flex-grow
docs.text:
Defines how much the item expands relative to others.

.item {
  flex-grow: 1;
}

docs.title: c) flex-shrink
docs.text:
Defines how much the item shrinks.

.item {
  flex-shrink: 0;
}

docs.title: d) flex-basis
docs.text:
Sets the initial size before growing/shrinking.

.item {
  flex-basis: 200px;
}

docs.title: e) Shorthand: flex
docs.text:
.item {
  flex: 1 1 200px; /* grow shrink basis */
}

docs.title: 10. align-self
docs.text:
Overrides align-items for a single item.

.item {
  align-self: center;
}

docs.title: Example Layout
docs.text:
.container {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  align-items: center;
}

<div class="container">
  <div>Item 1</div>
  <div>Item 2</div>
  <div>Item 3</div>
</div>

docs.title: Grid
docs.text: Grid is a 2-dimensional layout system for arranging items in rows and columns.

docs.title: 1. Enabling Grid
docs.text:
.container {
  display: grid;
}

All direct children become grid items.

docs.title: 2. Defining Columns and Rows
docs.text:
.container {
  grid-template-columns: 200px 1fr 2fr;
  grid-template-rows: 100px auto;
}
  • px = fixed size
  • fr = fraction of remaining space
  • auto = size based on content

docs.title: 3. Repeat Notation
docs.text:
grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);

Same as: 1fr 1fr 1fr

docs.title: 4. Gap Between Items
docs.text:
.container {
  gap: 20px; /* row + column gap */
}

Split version:

row-gap: 10px;
column-gap: 15px;

docs.title: 5. Placing Items
docs.text:
.item {
  grid-column: 1 / 3; /* spans columns 1 and 2 */
  grid-row: 2 / 4;
}

Or shorthand:

grid-area: row-start / column-start / row-end / column-end;

docs.title: 6. Named Areas
docs.text:
.container {
  grid-template-areas:
    "header header"
    "sidebar main"
    "footer footer";
}

.header {
  grid-area: header;
}

docs.title: 7. Implicit Tracks
docs.text:
Grid auto-generates rows/columns if needed.

.container {
  grid-auto-rows: 100px;
}

docs.title: 8. Auto-Placement
docs.text:
Items are placed in the next available cell by default.

.container {
  grid-auto-flow: row | column | dense;
}

docs.title: 9. Responsive Grid
docs.text:
.container {
  grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(200px, 1fr));
}

This makes columns responsive and wrap when space is tight.

docs.title: 10. Aligning Content
docs.text:
• Align grid items:
justify-items: start | center | end | stretch;
align-items: start | center | end | stretch;
  • Align the grid as a whole:
justify-content: center | space-between | space-around;
align-content: center;

docs.title: Transforms
docs.text: The transform property lets you apply 2D and 3D transformations to elements — such as rotating, scaling, moving, or skewing.

docs.title: 1. translate(x, y)
docs.text:
Moves an element from its current position.

.box {
  transform: translate(50px, 20px);
}
  • x = horizontal shift
  • y = vertical shift

docs.title: 2. scale(x, y)
docs.text:
Resizes the element.

.box {
  transform: scale(1.5); /* 1.5x both axes */
}

transform: scale(1.2, 0.8); /* x = 120%, y = 80% */

docs.title: 3. rotate(angle)
docs.text:
Rotates the element around its center.

.box {
  transform: rotate(45deg);
}

Use negative angles for counter-clockwise rotation.

docs.title: 4. skew(x, y)
docs.text:
Skews (slants) the element.

.box {
  transform: skew(20deg, 10deg);
}

docs.title: 5. Combine Multiple Transforms
docs.text:
.box {
  transform: translateX(50px) rotate(15deg) scale(1.2);
}

They are applied in order, left to right.

docs.title: 6. transform-origin
docs.text:
Sets the point of transformation.

.box {
  transform: rotate(45deg);
  transform-origin: top left;
}

Default is center center.

docs.title: 7. 3D Transforms (Basic)
docs.text:
Enable 3D perspective with:

.container {
  perspective: 1000px;
}

.box {
  transform: rotateY(45deg);
}

docs.title: 8. Performance Note
docs.text: Transforms are GPU-accelerated and more performant than changing top, left, etc. Use them for animations/movement.

docs.title: Transitions
docs.text: CSS transitions let you smoothly animate changes in CSS property values over time.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
.element {
  transition: property duration timing-function delay;
}

Example:

.button {
  background-color: blue;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease-in-out;
}

.button:hover {
  background-color: red;
}

When :hover is triggered, the background smoothly changes from blue to red.

docs.title: 2. Shorthand Breakdown
docs.text:
transition: all 0.5s ease 0.1s;
  • property — what to animate (color, all, etc.)
  • duration — how long the transition lasts (s or ms)
  • timing-function — how the animation accelerates
  • delay — time before transition starts

docs.title: 3. Timing Functions
docs.text: Value Description linear Constant speed ease Slow → fast → slow ease-in Slow start ease-out Slow end ease-in-out Slow start and end cubic-bezier(...) Custom easing curve

docs.title: 4. Multiple Properties
docs.text:
.box {
  transition: width 0.3s ease, background-color 0.3s linear;
}

Each property can have its own config.

docs.title: 5. Transitionable Properties
docs.text:
Only animatable properties can be transitioned:

✅ Examples:

  • color
  • background-color
  • width, height
  • transform
  • opacity
  • margin, padding

❌ Not animatable:

  • display
  • position
  • visibility (though can be paired with opacity)

docs.title: 6. Tips
docs.text:
• Use transition: all with caution — it's less performant and harder to debug.
  • Transitions only work when there's a change in property value (e.g. via :hover, .active, JS toggle).

docs.title: 7. Example: Button Hover
docs.text:
.button {
  background-color: #333;
  color: white;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease, transform 0.2s;
}

.button:hover {
  background-color: #555;
  transform: scale(1.05);
}

docs.title: Animations
docs.text: CSS animations let you create complex, keyframe-based transitions between styles over time — without JavaScript.

docs.title: 1. Basic Structure
docs.text:
.element {
  animation: name duration timing-function delay iteration-count direction fill-mode;
}

Only animation-name and animation-duration are required.

docs.title: 2. Example
docs.text:
@keyframes slideIn {
  from {
    transform: translateX(-100%);
  }
  to {
    transform: translateX(0);
  }
}

.box {
  animation: slideIn 0.5s ease-out;
}

docs.title: a) animation-name
docs.text:
The name of the @keyframes.

animation-name: fadeIn;

docs.title: b) animation-duration
docs.text:
How long the animation takes.

animation-duration: 1s;

docs.title: c) animation-timing-function
docs.text:
Controls animation pacing.

animation-timing-function: ease | linear | ease-in | ease-out | ease-in-out | cubic-bezier();

docs.title: d) animation-delay
docs.text:
Wait time before animation starts.

animation-delay: 0.5s;

docs.title: e) animation-iteration-count
docs.text:
Number of repeats.

animation-iteration-count: 3;   /* 3 times */
animation-iteration-count: infinite;

docs.title: f) animation-direction
docs.text:
Direction of each cycle.

normal | reverse | alternate | alternate-reverse;

docs.title: g) animation-fill-mode
docs.text:
Defines how styles apply before/after animation.

none | forwards | backwards | both;

Example:

animation-fill-mode: forwards;

Keeps final keyframe styles after animation ends.

docs.title: 4. Shorthand
docs.text: animation: fadeIn 1s ease-in 0.2s 1 normal forwards;

docs.title: 5. Pausing/Controlling
docs.text:
.element {
  animation-play-state: paused | running;
}

docs.title: 6. Multiple Animations
docs.text: animation: move 1s ease, fade 2s linear;

docs.title: 7. Example: Bounce
docs.text:
@keyframes bounce {
  0%, 100% {
    transform: translateY(0);
  }
  50% {
    transform: translateY(-20px);
  }
}

.ball {
  animation: bounce 0.6s infinite;
}

docs.title: object-fit and object-position
docs.text: The object-fit property defines how content like images or videos are resized to fit their container.

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text:
img {
  object-fit: value;
}

docs.title: Values:
docs.text: Value Description fill Default. Stretches to fill container — may distort aspect ratio. contain Fits inside container without cropping — maintains aspect ratio. cover Fills entire container — may crop, maintains aspect ratio. none Image keeps original size — no resize. scale-down Chooses the smaller result of none or contain.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
img {
  width: 300px;
  height: 200px;
  object-fit: cover;
}

Result: The image fills the 300×200 box, cropped if necessary.

docs.title: 2. object-position
docs.text: Controls alignment of the image inside its box when object-fit ≠ fill.

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text:
img {
  object-position: center top;
}

docs.title: Common values:
docs.text:
• center, top, bottom, left, right
  • You can also use px, %

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
img {
  object-fit: cover;
  object-position: top;
}

Result: Image fills the container, cropping from the bottom if needed.

docs.title: 3. Practical Use Case: Responsive Image Crop
docs.text:
img {
  width: 100%;
  height: 300px;
  object-fit: cover;
  object-position: center;
}
  • Maintains aspect ratio
  • Crops the excess
  • Ensures consistent layout

docs.title: Filters
docs.text: The filter property applies visual effects (like blur, brightness, contrast, etc.) to elements — especially images and backgrounds.

docs.title: 1. Syntax
docs.text:
.element {
  filter: filter-function(value);
}

Multiple filters can be chained:

filter: brightness(1.2) contrast(90%) saturate(150%);

docs.title: a) blur(px)
docs.text:
Applies Gaussian blur.

filter: blur(5px);

docs.title: b) brightness(%)
docs.text:
Controls light intensity.

filter: brightness(150%); /* brighter */
filter: brightness(50%);  /* darker */

docs.title: c) contrast(%)
docs.text:
Adjusts contrast.

filter: contrast(200%);

docs.title: d) grayscale(%)
docs.text:
Converts to grayscale.

filter: grayscale(100%);

docs.title: e) sepia(%)
docs.text:
Applies a warm, brown tone.

filter: sepia(100%);

docs.title: f) saturate(%)
docs.text:
Controls color intensity.

filter: saturate(200%);

docs.title: g) hue-rotate(deg)
docs.text:
Shifts hue (color spectrum rotation).

filter: hue-rotate(90deg);

docs.title: h) invert(%)
docs.text:
Inverts colors.

filter: invert(100%);

docs.title: i) opacity(%)
docs.text:
Sets element transparency.

filter: opacity(70%);

docs.title: 3. Example: Hover Filter
docs.text:
img {
  filter: grayscale(100%);
  transition: filter 0.3s;
}

img:hover {
  filter: grayscale(0%);
}

docs.title: 4. Notes
docs.text:
• Filters affect rendering — may impact performance.
  • Works on most elements (<img>, <div>, pseudo-elements, etc.).
  • Combine with transitions for smooth effects.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Express.js is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides robust features for building web and mobile applications. It simplifies the process of handling routes, requests, responses, and middleware in Node.js.

docs.title: 1. Why Use Express.js?
docs.text:
• Simplifies building server-side applications with Node.js
  • Provides routing, middleware, and templating support
  • Lightweight and fast
  • Widely used in building REST APIs and full-stack apps
  • Easy integration with databases like MongoDB, MySQL, PostgreSQL

docs.title: 2. Installation
docs.text:
First, initialize a Node.js project:

mkdir express-app
cd express-app
npm init -y

Install Express:

npm install express

docs.title: 3. Basic Express Server
docs.text:
const express = require("express");
const app = express();
const PORT = 3000;

app.get("/", (req, res) => {
  res.send("Hello, Express!");
});

app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on http://localhost:${PORT}`);
});
  • express() creates an Express app
  • app.get(path, callback) handles GET requests
  • res.send() sends a response
  • app.listen() starts the server

docs.title: 4. Handling Different Routes
docs.text:
app.get("/about", (req, res) => {
  res.send("About Page");
});

app.post("/submit", (req, res) => {
  res.send("Form Submitted");
});

docs.title: 5. Route Parameters (req.params)
docs.text:
Route parameters allow you to capture values from the URL.

app.get("/users/:id", (req, res) => {
  const userId = req.params.id;
  res.send(`User ID: ${userId}`);
});
  • Visiting /users/42 → req.params.id is "42"
  • Useful for dynamic routes like user profiles, product pages, etc.

Multiple parameters:

app.get("/posts/:postId/comments/:commentId", (req, res) => {
  const { postId, commentId } = req.params;
  res.send(`Post ID: ${postId}, Comment ID: ${commentId}`);
});

docs.title: 6. Middleware
docs.text:
Middleware functions are functions that run before reaching the final route handler. They can modify req and res.

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log(`${req.method} ${req.url}`);
  next();
});

docs.title: 7. Serving Static Files
docs.text:
app.use(express.static("public"));

Now you can serve files like public/index.html.

docs.title: 8. JSON Data Handling
docs.text:
app.use(express.json());

app.post("/data", (req, res) => {
  res.json({ received: req.body });
});
  • express.json() parses JSON request bodies

docs.title: 9. Express Routing in Separate Files
docs.text:
// routes/user.js
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();

router.get("/", (req, res) => res.send("User List"));
router.get("/:id", (req, res) => res.send(`User ${req.params.id}`));

module.exports = router;

// app.js
const userRoutes = require("./routes/user");
app.use("/users", userRoutes);

Visiting /users/ → "User List" Visiting /users/42 → "User 42"

docs.title: Response
docs.text: In Express.js, the response object (res) represents the HTTP response that an Express app sends when it receives a request.

docs.title: Common Response Methods
docs.text:
res.send("Hello, World!");      // Sends plain text/HTML
res.json({ name: "Ronald" });     // Sends JSON response
res.status(404).send("Not Found"); // Sets status code
res.redirect("/home");          // Redirects to another route
res.download("file.pdf");       // Prompts file download
res.end();                      // Ends the response process
  • res.send() → Sends text, HTML, or JSON automatically detected
  • res.json() → Always sends JSON
  • res.status() → Sets HTTP status code
  • res.redirect() → Redirects to another URL

docs.title: Request
docs.text: The request object (req) contains all information about the HTTP request.

docs.title: Common Request Properties
docs.text:
app.get("/profile/:id", (req, res) => {
  console.log(req.params.id);     // Route params
  console.log(req.query.name);    // Query string ?name=aman
  console.log(req.body);          // Data from POST/PUT body
  console.log(req.method);        // HTTP method (GET, POST, etc.)
  console.log(req.url);           // URL of the request
  res.send("Profile Page");
});
  • req.params → Dynamic route parameters
  • req.query → Query string parameters
  • req.body → Data sent in the request body (requires middleware like express.json())
  • req.method → HTTP method
  • req.url → Request URL

docs.title: Routers
docs.text: Routers help organize routes into separate files for better structure.

docs.title: Example of Router
docs.text:
// routes/user.js
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();

router.get("/", (req, res) => res.send("User List"));
router.post("/", (req, res) => res.send("Create User"));
router.get("/:id", (req, res) => res.send(`User ${req.params.id}`));

module.exports = router;

docs.title: Using Router in Main App
docs.text:
// app.js
const express = require("express");
const app = express();
const userRoutes = require("./routes/user");

app.use("/users", userRoutes);

app.listen(3000, () => console.log("Server running on port 3000"));
  • Visiting /users/ → "User List"
  • Visiting /users/42 → "User 42"
  • Visiting /users with POST → "Create User"

docs.title: Middlewares
docs.text: Middleware functions in Express.js are functions that execute before the final route handler. They can modify the request (req), response (res), or even end the request-response cycle.

docs.title: Basic Example
docs.text:
const express = require("express");
const app = express();

// Middleware function
app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log(`${req.method} ${req.url}`);
  next(); // Passes control to the next middleware/route
});

app.get("/", (req, res) => {
  res.send("Home Page");
});

app.listen(3000, () => console.log("Server running on port 3000"));
  • app.use() → Adds middleware to the entire app
  • next() → Moves to the next middleware or route handler

docs.title: 1. Application-Level Middleware
docs.text:
app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log("Application-level middleware executed");
  next();
});

Applies to all routes unless restricted by path:

app.use("/api", (req, res, next) => { ... });

docs.title: 2. Router-Level Middleware
docs.text:
Used with express.Router() to apply middleware only to specific routers.

const router = express.Router();

router.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log("Router-level middleware");
  next();
});

router.get("/", (req, res) => res.send("Users"));

app.use("/users", router);

docs.title: 3. Built-in Middleware
docs.text:
• express.json() → Parses JSON data
  • express.urlencoded({ extended: true }) → Parses URL-encoded form data
  • express.static("public") → Serves static files
app.use(express.json());
app.use(express.static("public"));

docs.title: 4. Third-Party Middleware
docs.text:
You can install and use external middleware packages.

npm install morgan cors

const morgan = require("morgan");
const cors = require("cors");

app.use(morgan("dev")); // Logs requests
app.use(cors());        // Enables CORS

docs.title: 5. Error-Handling Middleware
docs.text:
Used to handle errors globally. Must have four parameters.

app.use((err, req, res, next) => {
  console.error(err.stack);
  res.status(500).send("Something broke!");
});

docs.title: Middleware Flow Example
docs.text:
app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log("First middleware");
  next();
});

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  console.log("Second middleware");
  next();
});

app.get("/", (req, res) => {
  res.send("Final Route Handler");
});

Output:

First middleware
Second middleware

Then the response “Final Route Handler” is sent.

docs.title: What is EJS?
docs.text: EJS is a simple templating language that lets you generate HTML markup with plain JavaScript. It is commonly used with Node.js for server-side rendering of dynamic content.

docs.title: Advantages of EJS
docs.text:
• Simple to learn for those familiar with JavaScript.
  • Allows embedding JavaScript logic directly in HTML.
  • Supports partials for reusable components.
  • Works seamlessly with Express.js.

docs.title: Disadvantages
docs.text:
• Logic-heavy templates can get messy.
  • Not as modern as React, Vue, or other component-based frameworks.

docs.title: Project Structure (Node.js + Express)
docs.text:
my-ejs-project/
│
├── package.json
├── package-lock.json
├── server.js            # Main server file
│
├── views/               # All EJS templates
   ├── partials/        # Reusable components (header, footer)
   │   ├── header.ejs
   │   └── footer.ejs
   ├── index.ejs
   ├── about.ejs
   └── contact.ejs

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install ejs

docs.title: Setting Up EJS with Express
docs.text:
const express = require('express');
const app = express();

// Set EJS as the template engine
app.set('view engine', 'ejs');

// Optional: Set views directory
app.set('views', './views');

app.listen(3000, () => console.log('Server running on port 3000'));

docs.title: Creating an EJS Template
docs.text:
views/index.ejs

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title><%= title %></title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Hello, <%= name %>!</h1>
    <ul>
        <% items.forEach(item => { %>
            <li><%= item %></li>
        <% }) %>
    </ul>
</body>
</html>

docs.title: Rendering EJS Templates
docs.text:
app.get('/', (req, res) => {
    res.render('index', {
        title: 'My EJS Page',
        name: 'John',
        items: ['Item 1', 'Item 2', 'Item 3']
    });
});

docs.title: Output HTML
docs.text:
• <%= variable %> → Outputs the value and escapes HTML
  • <%- variable %> → Outputs unescaped HTML

docs.title: JavaScript Code
docs.text: • <% code %> → Executes JavaScript code (no output)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
<% if(user) { %>
    <p>Welcome, <%= user.name %>!</p>
<% } else { %>
    <p>Please log in.</p>
<% } %>

docs.title: Partial Templates (Include)
docs.text:
views/header.ejs

<header>
    <h1>My Website</h1>
</header>

Include in main template:

<%- include('header') %>

docs.title: Loops & Conditionals
docs.text:
<ul>
<% for(let i=0; i<items.length; i++) { %>
    <li><%= items[i] %></li>
<% } %>
</ul>

<% if(items.length > 0) { %>
    <p>We have items!</p>
<% } else { %>
    <p>No items found.</p>
<% } %>

docs.title: What is Git?
docs.text: Git is a distributed version control system (VCS) used to track changes in source code during software development. It allows multiple developers to collaborate efficiently by managing versions of code and merging updates seamlessly.

docs.title: Key Features of Git
docs.text:
• Distributed System: Every developer has a local copy of the repository.
  • Version Tracking: Tracks every change made to files.
  • Branching & Merging: Enables developers to create independent branches for new features and merge them later.
  • Collaboration: Facilitates teamwork through remote repositories like GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
  • Data Integrity: Uses SHA-1 hashing to ensure code integrity.
  • Lightweight & Fast: Most operations are done locally, ensuring speed.

docs.title: Basic Git Terminology
docs.text: Term Description Repository (Repo) A project folder tracked by Git containing all files and their history. Commit A snapshot of changes made to the code. Branch A separate line of development for new features or experiments. Merge Combining changes from one branch into another. Clone Copying a remote repository to your local system. Pull Fetching and merging changes from a remote repo. Push Uploading local commits to a remote repo. Staging Area Temporary area where changes are prepared before committing. Remote A version of the repository hosted online.

docs.title: Git Workflow
docs.text:
1. Clone or Initialize Repository
git clone <repo-url>
# or
git init
  1. Make Changes Edit or create files.
  2. Check Status
git status
  1. Add to Staging Area
git add <filename>
# or all files
git add .
  1. Commit Changes
git commit -m "Describe your changes"
  1. Push to Remote
git push origin main
  1. Pull Latest Updates
git pull origin main

docs.title: Create a Branch
docs.text: git branch feature-xyz

docs.title: Switch to Branch
docs.text: git checkout feature-xyz

docs.title: Merge Branch
docs.text:
git checkout main
git merge feature-xyz

docs.title: Delete Branch
docs.text: git branch -d feature-xyz

docs.title: Viewing History
docs.text:
• Commit Log
git log
  • Short Log
git log --oneline
  • Show Changes
git diff

docs.title: Undoing Changes
docs.text:
• Unstage a File
git reset <file>
  • Undo Last Commit (Keep Changes)
git reset --soft HEAD~1
  • Discard Local Changes
git checkout -- <file>

docs.title: Add Remote
docs.text: git remote add origin <repo-url>

docs.title: View Remotes
docs.text: git remote -v

docs.title: Push Changes
docs.text: git push origin main

docs.title: Fetch Remote Changes
docs.text: git fetch origin

docs.title: Common Git Commands Summary
docs.text: Command Description git init Initialize a new Git repository git clone <url> Clone a remote repository git status Check status of working directory git add . Stage all changes git commit -m "message" Save changes git push Upload commits to remote git pull Download and merge remote changes git branch List branches git checkout <branch> Switch branches git merge <branch> Merge branch into current git log View commit history

docs.title: .gitignore
docs.text:
A special file used to tell Git which files/folders to ignore (not track). Example:

node_modules/
.env
*.log

docs.title: Git Configurations
docs.text:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
git config --list

docs.title: Git Stash
docs.text:
Temporarily saves uncommitted changes.

git stash
git stash list
git stash pop

docs.title: Git Rebase
docs.text:
Reapply commits on top of another base branch (used to clean commit history).

git rebase main

docs.title: Git Tag
docs.text:
Mark specific commits as versions.

git tag v1.0
git push origin v1.0

docs.title: What is GitHub
docs.text: GitHub is a cloud-based platform for version control and collaboration built around Git. It allows developers to store, track, and manage code changes, work together on projects, and maintain repositories.

docs.title: 1. Repository (Repo)
docs.text:
A repository is a folder where your project files and their version history are stored. It can be:

  • Public → visible to everyone.
  • Private → visible only to you and collaborators.

docs.title: 2. Commit
docs.text:
A snapshot of your code at a specific time. Each commit has:

  • A commit message describing the change.
  • A unique hash ID for reference.

docs.title: 3. Branch
docs.text:
Branches allow you to work on different features without affecting the main code.

  • main/master → stable production version.
  • feature branches → for new features or bug fixes.

docs.title: 4. Pull Request (PR)
docs.text:
A request to merge changes from one branch (like feature) into another (like main). Used in team projects for:

  • Code review
  • Discussion
  • Testing before merging

docs.title: 5. Merge
docs.text: Combining changes from different branches. Usually happens after a pull request is approved.

docs.title: 6. Fork
docs.text:
A copy of another user’s repository on your own account. Used to:

  • Contribute to open-source projects
  • Experiment with code without affecting the original repo

docs.title: 7. Clone
docs.text:
Download a repository from GitHub to your local machine using:

git clone <repo-url>

docs.title: 8. Remote
docs.text:
A version of your project hosted on GitHub. The local and remote repositories sync through commands like:

git push      # Upload changes
git pull      # Download updates
git fetch     # Get changes without merging

docs.title: 1. Issues
docs.text:
Used to track bugs, enhancements, or tasks. Each issue can have:

  • Labels
  • Assignees
  • Comments

docs.title: 2. Projects
docs.text: Visual boards to organize work (like Kanban or Scrum boards).

docs.title: 3. Actions (CI/CD)
docs.text:
Automate workflows such as:

  • Testing code
  • Building projects
  • Deploying applications

Example YAML file:

name: Node.js CI
on: [push]
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - run: npm install
      - run: npm test

docs.title: 4. Discussions
docs.text: For community Q&A and brainstorming ideas.

docs.title: 5. Wiki
docs.text: A built-in documentation system for repositories.

docs.title: 6. Releases
docs.text: Used to package and version software with changelogs and assets.

docs.title: GitHub Commands (Basic)
docs.text:
git init                 # Initialize new Git repo
git clone <url>          # Clone remote repo
git add .                # Stage all changes
git commit -m "message"  # Commit changes
git push origin main     # Push changes to GitHub
git pull origin main     # Pull latest changes
git branch               # List branches
git checkout -b feature  # Create and switch to a new branch
git merge feature         # Merge feature branch into current

docs.title: GitHub Collaboration Workflow
docs.text:
1. Fork the main repository
  2. Clone it locally
  3. Create a new branch
  4. Make changes and commit
  5. Push branch to GitHub
  6. Create Pull Request
  7. Wait for review and merge

  • README Profile: Personal introduction using markdown.
  • Contributions Graph: Shows daily coding activity.
  • Stars: Show appreciation for other repos.
  • Followers/Following: Build a developer network.

docs.title: What is Hosting?
docs.text: Hosting is a service that allows individuals or organizations to make their websites accessible on the internet. When you host a website, you store its files (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, images, databases, etc.) on a server connected to the internet 24/7. When someone types your website’s domain name into a browser, the hosting server delivers the files to their device.

docs.title: How Hosting Works
docs.text:
1. Website Creation: You build your website using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and other technologies.
  2. Choose a Hosting Provider: You rent space on a server from companies like Hostinger, GoDaddy, or AWS.
  3. Upload Files: Website files are uploaded to the hosting server using FTP or a control panel.
  4. Connect Domain: The domain name (e.g., example.com) is linked to the server using DNS.
  5. Access by Visitors: When users enter the domain name, the DNS finds the server’s IP address, and the website loads in their browser.

docs.title: Difference Between Domain and Hosting
docs.text:
Feature Domain Hosting Definition The web address users type to visit your website (e.g., example.com) The storage space where your website files are kept Purpose Identifies your website on the internet Stores and serves website content Analogy Like a home address Like the actual house

Example: If your website is a house:

  • The domain is the address (123 Street Name).
  • The hosting is the land where the house (website files) sits.

docs.title: 1. Server
docs.text: A powerful computer that stores your website files and runs 24/7 to make your website available online.

docs.title: 2. DNS (Domain Name System)
docs.text: Converts your domain name into an IP address that browsers use to find the hosting server.

docs.title: 3. FTP (File Transfer Protocol)
docs.text: A method used to upload and manage files on your hosting server. You can use tools like FileZilla.

docs.title: 4. Control Panel
docs.text: A graphical interface (like cPanel, Plesk) provided by the hosting company to manage your website, emails, and databases.

docs.title: 5. Database
docs.text: Stores dynamic website content such as user accounts, blog posts, or product data (e.g., MySQL, MongoDB).

docs.title: Importance of Hosting
docs.text:
• Keeps your website accessible 24/7
  • Provides storage for your website files
  • Ensures speed and reliability through server performance
  • Offers security features like SSL, backups, and firewalls
  • Allows scaling as your website grows

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text:
You build a portfolio website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript:

  1. You purchase a domain — portfolio.com
  2. You choose hosting — e.g., Netlify or Hostinger
  3. You upload your files to the hosting server
  4. When someone visits portfolio.com, the server sends your site’s files to their browser

This is how hosting makes your website live on the internet.

docs.title: Types of Hosting
docs.text: Hosting comes in various types depending on performance needs, pricing, scalability, and control. Each type offers different levels of resource sharing, management, and customization.

docs.title: 1. Shared Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: Multiple websites share the same physical server and its resources such as CPU, RAM, and bandwidth.

Pros:

  • Cheapest hosting option
  • Easy to set up and use
  • Usually includes a control panel (like cPanel)

Cons:

  • Slower performance (shared resources)
  • Limited customization
  • If one website gets high traffic, others slow down
  • Weaker security (shared environment)

Best For: Small websites, blogs, portfolios, and beginners.

docs.title: 2. VPS (Virtual Private Server) Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: A single physical server is divided into multiple virtual servers. Each has its own resources and acts like a dedicated server.

Pros:

  • Better performance than shared hosting
  • Root access for full control
  • Scalable (add more resources when needed)

Cons:

  • More expensive than shared hosting
  • Requires technical knowledge to manage

Best For: Medium-sized websites, growing businesses, and developers who need more control.

docs.title: 3. Dedicated Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: You rent an entire physical server for your website — no sharing with others.

Pros:

  • Maximum performance and control
  • Highest security level
  • Fully customizable environment

Cons:

  • Very expensive
  • Needs server management skills
  • Overkill for small sites

Best For: Large enterprises, e-commerce platforms, or high-traffic websites.

docs.title: 4. Cloud Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: Your website is hosted on a cluster of servers (the cloud). If one server fails, another automatically takes over.

Pros:

  • Highly scalable and reliable
  • Pay only for what you use
  • Excellent uptime and performance

Cons:

  • Can get expensive as usage grows
  • Slightly complex to configure

Best For: Startups, growing websites, and apps with fluctuating traffic.

docs.title: 5. Managed Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: The hosting provider manages technical operations like updates, backups, and maintenance for you.

Pros:

  • Hassle-free management
  • High security and reliability
  • Expert support

Cons:

  • More expensive
  • Less manual control over the server

Best For: Non-technical users or teams that prefer focusing on business rather than server management.

docs.title: 6. WordPress Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: Hosting optimized specifically for WordPress websites with pre-installed plugins, caching, and updates.

Pros:

  • Fast setup and optimized performance
  • Automatic updates and backups
  • Security tuned for WordPress

Cons:

  • Limited to WordPress sites
  • Less flexibility for custom setups

Best For: WordPress blogs, business sites, and portfolios.

docs.title: 7. Reseller Hosting
docs.text:
Definition: You rent hosting resources and resell them to others under your own brand.

Pros:

  • Great for starting a web hosting business
  • Manage multiple clients easily
  • Includes management panels for reselling

Cons:

  • Requires business and management skills
  • You’re responsible for client issues

Best For: Entrepreneurs, freelancers, or agencies managing multiple websites.

docs.title: Setup and Deployment
docs.text: Hosting your website involves preparing files, selecting a hosting provider, connecting your domain, and uploading your project to a live server. This process is known as deployment.

docs.title: Step 1: Build Your Website
docs.text:
Create your project using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, or frameworks like React, Node.js, etc. Ensure your files are organized, for example:

/project-folder
├── index.html
├── about.html
├── styles.css
├── script.js
└── /images

docs.title: Step 2: Choose a Hosting Provider
docs.text:
Select a hosting type based on your website:

  • Static website: Netlify, Vercel, GitHub Pages
  • Dynamic / Full-stack app: Render, Railway, AWS, DigitalOcean
  • WordPress site: Bluehost, Hostinger

docs.title: Step 3: Get a Domain Name
docs.text:
Purchase a domain name (e.g., yourname.com) from:

  • Domain registrars like Namecheap, GoDaddy, or Google Domains
  • Some hosting providers include a free domain in their plans

docs.title: Step 4: Connect Domain to Hosting
docs.text:
To link your domain with your hosting server, update the DNS records:

Record Type Purpose Example A Record Points domain to server IP example.com → 192.168.1.1 CNAME Points subdomain to another domain www → example.com MX Handles email routing mail.example.com

Note: DNS changes can take up to 24–48 hours to fully update (DNS propagation).

docs.title: Step 5: Upload Website Files
docs.text: There are several ways to upload your project files:

docs.title: Option 1: File Manager (via cPanel)
docs.text:
1. Log in to your hosting cPanel.
  2. Open File Manager → public_html folder.
  3. Upload your files and extract (if zipped).
  4. Visit your domain to see your live website.

docs.title: Option 2: FTP (File Transfer Protocol)
docs.text:
1. Install an FTP client like FileZilla.
  2. Enter your FTP credentials from your hosting account.
  3. Connect to the server.
  4. Drag and drop your website files to the server’s root folder.

docs.title: Option 3: Git-Based Deployment
docs.text:
For providers like Netlify, Vercel, or Render:

  1. Push your project to GitHub / GitLab / Bitbucket.
  2. Link your repository to the hosting platform.
  3. The platform automatically deploys your site on every push.

docs.title: Frontend + Backend Example
docs.text:
If you built a MERN stack app:

  • Frontend (React): Host on Vercel or Netlify.
  • Backend (Node.js/Express): Host on Render or Railway.
  • Database: Use MongoDB Atlas or Firebase.

Steps:

  1. Deploy backend → get API URL (e.g., https://api.render.com).
  2. Update frontend .env or config with API URL.
  3. Deploy frontend → site connects to live backend.

docs.title: 3. Continuous Deployment (CD)
docs.text:
Most modern hosts like Vercel, Netlify, and Render support automatic deployment:

  • Whenever you push new code to GitHub → your live website updates automatically. This is known as Continuous Deployment or CI/CD.

docs.title: 4. Verifying Deployment
docs.text:
After deployment:

  • Visit your website URL (e.g., https://myproject.netlify.app).
  • Check responsiveness and loading speed.
  • Test all links, forms, and APIs.
  • Enable SSL (HTTPS) from your hosting dashboard.

docs.title: 5. Common Deployment Issues
docs.text: Issue Cause Solution Site not loading Wrong DNS setup Verify A/CNAME records Files not visible Uploaded to wrong directory Use public_html or root folder Changes not updating Cached version Clear cache / redeploy SSL not working Not enabled Activate SSL from dashboard 404 Errors Wrong paths Check file names and routes

docs.title: 1. Uptime
docs.text:
• Meaning: Percentage of time your website stays online and accessible.
  • Good Standard: 99.9% or higher.
  • Why It Matters: Even small downtime can cause user loss, lower SEO ranking, and affect trust.

  • Example:

  • 99.9% uptime = ~43 minutes of downtime per month

  • 99.99% uptime = ~4 minutes per month

docs.title: 2. Bandwidth
docs.text:
• Meaning: Amount of data transferred between your website and users per month.
  • High Bandwidth: Needed for large websites, videos, and many visitors.
  • Low Bandwidth: Fine for small or static sites.
  • Tip: Choose “unmetered” or “unlimited” bandwidth if your website will grow.

docs.title: 3. Storage
docs.text:
• Meaning: The total space on the server to store your files, databases, and emails.
  • Static Sites: Require only a few hundred MBs.
  • Dynamic / Media Sites: Need more (5GB+).
  • SSD Hosting: Prefer SSD over HDD for faster performance.

docs.title: 4. SSL Certificate
docs.text:
• Purpose: Encrypts data between the website and visitors using HTTPS.

  • Benefits:

  • Increases security and trust.

  • Improves SEO ranking.
  • Prevents data theft.
  • Tip: Most hosts offer Free SSL (Let’s Encrypt).

docs.title: 5. Scalability
docs.text:
• Meaning: Ability to upgrade or increase server resources as your website grows.
  • Why Important: Prevents slowdowns or crashes during traffic spikes.
  • Cloud and VPS hosting are best for scalability.

docs.title: 6. Backup Options
docs.text:
• Automatic Backups: Scheduled daily or weekly by the host.
  • Manual Backups: You can create and download copies.
  • Importance: Essential for data recovery after hacks or errors.
  • Tip: Always keep an offsite backup (e.g., Google Drive, Dropbox).

docs.title: 7. Security Features
docs.text:
• Firewall: Blocks malicious traffic.
  • DDoS Protection: Prevents overload attacks.
  • Malware Scanning: Detects and removes infected files.
  • Two-Factor Authentication (2FA): Adds login security.
  • SSL Encryption: Protects data in transit.

docs.title: 8. Customer Support
docs.text:
• 24/7 Availability: Through chat, email, or tickets.
  • Technical Assistance: Helps with setup, bugs, and downtime issues.
  • Knowledge Base: Tutorials and guides for self-help.
  • Tip: Always test response speed before buying hosting.

docs.title: 9. Control Panel
docs.text:
• Purpose: Interface to manage your hosting account.

  • Popular Panels:

  • cPanel (most common)

  • Plesk
  • DirectAdmin

  • Features:

  • File management

  • Database control
  • Domain and email setup
  • Backup and app installation

docs.title: 10. Email Hosting
docs.text:
• Custom Email: Example — info@yourdomain.com
  • Storage and Spam Protection: Should include filters and enough space.
  • Integration: Can connect with Gmail or Outlook for convenience.

docs.title: 11. Database Support
docs.text:
• MySQL / PostgreSQL: Common for WordPress and PHP sites.
  • MongoDB / NoSQL: Used in modern full-stack (MERN) apps.
  • Requirement: Check version support and remote access capability.

docs.title: 12. Server Location
docs.text:
• Closer Server = Faster Load Time
  • Choose server region near your target audience.

  • Example:

  • India → Mumbai server

  • USA → Dallas or New York server
  • Some providers allow CDN integration for global speed.

docs.title: 13. Performance Optimization
docs.text:
• Caching: Reduces load on the server.
  • CDN (Content Delivery Network): Delivers data faster worldwide.
  • LiteSpeed / NGINX Servers: Offer higher performance than Apache.
  • Resource Monitoring: Helps track CPU, RAM, and disk usage.

docs.title: 14. Pricing and Renewal
docs.text:
• Introductory Offers: Cheap first year, higher renewal cost.
  • Hidden Charges: Check for migration or SSL renewal fees.
  • Tip: Compare 1-year vs 3-year plans for better long-term savings.

docs.title: 15. Developer Features (for advanced users)
docs.text:
• SSH Access: For command-line control.
  • Git Integration: For version control and deployment.
  • Node.js / Python / PHP Support: Depends on hosting type.
  • API Access: For automation and advanced configurations.

docs.title: What is HTML?
docs.text: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard markup language used to create and structure content on the web.

docs.title: Key Points:
docs.text:
• HTML describes the structure of a web page using elements (also called tags).
  • Elements are enclosed in angle brackets: <tagname>...</tagname>.
  • Most elements have an opening tag, content, and a closing tag.
  • HTML files use the .html extension.

docs.title: Basic Boilerplate:
docs.text:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
    <title>Page Title</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello World!</h1>
  </body>
</html>

docs.title: Explanation of Each Part:
docs.text: Section Purpose <!DOCTYPE html> Declares the document type and version (HTML5). Must be the first line. <html lang="en"> Root element of the page. lang="en" indicates English content. <head> Contains metadata about the document (not visible content). <meta charset="UTF-8"> Sets the character encoding (UTF-8 supports all characters). <meta name="viewport"...> Ensures the site is mobile responsive by controlling page scaling. <title> Sets the title shown in the browser tab. <body> Contains everything visible on the page (text, images, elements, etc).

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
<!-- up to <h6> -->

docs.title: Paragraphs
docs.text: <p>This is a paragraph.</p>

docs.title: Links
docs.text: <a href="https://example.com">Visit Example</a>

docs.title: Images
docs.text: <img src="image.jpg" alt="Description of image" />

docs.title: Unordered:
docs.text:
<ul>
  <li>Item 1</li>
  <li>Item 2</li>
</ul>

docs.title: Ordered:
docs.text:
<ol>
  <li>First</li>
  <li>Second</li>
</ol>

docs.title: Line Break & Horizontal Rule
docs.text:
<br>   <!-- Line break -->
<hr>   <!-- Horizontal line -->

docs.title: Nesting and Indentation
docs.text:
Elements can be nested inside others. Always indent child elements to improve readability.

<ul>
  <li>
    <a href="#">Nested Link</a>
  </li>
</ul>

docs.title: Comments in HTML
docs.text:
<!-- This is a comment -->

Used to add notes or temporarily disable parts of code.

docs.title: 🔹<div> — Block-level Container
docs.text:
• Block-level element
  • Takes up the full width of its parent
  • Starts on a new line
  • Commonly used to group large sections of HTML

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
<div>

docs.title: Variables
docs.text: Variables are used to store data that can be referenced and manipulated later.

docs.title: a) var
docs.text:
• Function-scoped
  • Hoisted (can be used before declaration, but unsafe)
  • Avoid using in modern code
var x = 10;

docs.title: b) let
docs.text:
• Block-scoped
  • Can be reassigned
  • Preferred for values that change
let count = 5;
count = 6;

docs.title: c) const
docs.text:
• Block-scoped
  • Cannot be reassigned
  • Must be initialized when declared
  • Use for constants or fixed references
const PI = 3.14;

docs.title: 2. Naming Rules
docs.text:
• Case-sensitive
  • Must start with letter, _, or $
  • Can’t start with a number
  • Use camelCase for naming (userName, totalPrice)

const MAX_SCORE = 100;

docs.title: 3. Hoisting Behavior
docs.text:
• var is hoisted (declared at top of scope), but value is undefined
  • let and const are hoisted but not initialized (Temporal Dead Zone)
console.log(x); // undefined
var x = 10;

console.log(y); // ReferenceError
let y = 20;

docs.title: Conditionals
docs.text: Conditionals control the flow of code by executing different blocks based on true/false evaluations.

docs.title: 1. if Statement
docs.text:
let age = 18;

if (age >= 18) {
  console.log("Adult");
}

docs.title: 2. if...else
docs.text:
if (age >= 18) {
  console.log("Adult");
} else {
  console.log("Minor");
}

if (age < 13) {
  console.log("Child");
} else if (age < 18) {
  console.log("Teen");
} else {
  console.log("Adult");
}
