docs.text: Operator Name Example Result && AND a > 0 && b > 0 true if both ` ` OR `a > 0 b > 0` true if either ! NOT !isLoggedIn inverse

docs.title: 6. switch Statement
docs.text:
Efficient alternative to multiple if...else if.

let color = "blue";

switch (color) {
  case "red":
    console.log("Red selected");
    break;
  case "blue":
    console.log("Blue selected");
    break;
  default:
    console.log("No match");
}
  • break is required to prevent fall-through
  • default runs if no case matches

docs.title: 7. Falsy Values
docs.text:
These values are considered false in conditionals:

  • false
  • 0
  • "" (empty string)
  • null
  • undefined
  • NaN
if (!value) {
  console.log("Falsy value");
}

docs.title: Loops
docs.text: Loops let you repeat a block of code multiple times, either a fixed number of times or until a condition fails.

docs.title: 1. for Loop
docs.text:
Use when the number of iterations is known.

for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  console.log(i);
}
  • i = 0 → start
  • i < 5 → condition
  • i++ → increment

docs.title: 2. while Loop
docs.text:
Runs while the condition is true.

let i = 0;
while (i < 5) {
  console.log(i);
  i++;
}

docs.title: 3. do...while Loop
docs.text:
Runs at least once, then checks the condition.

let i = 0;
do {
  console.log(i);
  i++;
} while (i < 5);

docs.title: 4. for...of Loop
docs.text:
Iterates over iterables like arrays, strings, etc.

let nums = [10, 20, 30];

for (let num of nums) {
  console.log(num);
}

docs.title: 5. for...in Loop
docs.text:
Iterates over keys in an object.

const user = { name: "John", age: 30 };

for (let key in user) {
  console.log(key, user[key]);
}

docs.title: break: exits the loop early.
docs.text:
for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  if (i === 5) break;
  console.log(i); // 0 to 4
}

docs.title: continue: skips current iteration.
docs.text:
for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  if (i === 2) continue;
  console.log(i); // 0, 1, 3, 4
}

docs.title: 7. Looping Arrays with .forEach()
docs.text:
let arr = [1, 2, 3];

arr.forEach(function (val) {
  console.log(val);
});

docs.title: Functions
docs.text: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. You define them once and call them anywhere.

docs.title: 1. Function Declaration
docs.text:
function greet() {
  console.log("Hello");
}

greet(); // Call the function

docs.title: 2. Parameters & Arguments
docs.text:
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

let result = add(5, 3); // 8
  • a, b → parameters (placeholders)
  • 5, 3 → arguments (actual values)

docs.title: 3. Return Value
docs.text:
Use return to send a value back.

function multiply(x, y) {
  return x * y;
}

If no return, the function returns undefined.

docs.title: 4. Function Expression
docs.text:
Function stored in a variable.

const greet = function () {
  console.log("Hi");
};

greet();

docs.title: 5. Arrow Functions (ES6)
docs.text:
Shorter syntax, often used for callbacks.

const add = (a, b) => a + b;

With multiple lines:

const greet = () => {
  console.log("Hello");
};

docs.title: 6. Default Parameters
docs.text:
function sayHello(name = "Guest") {
  console.log("Hello, " + name);
}

sayHello(); // "Hello, Guest"

docs.title: 7. Rest Parameters
docs.text:
Combines multiple arguments into an array.

function sum(...nums) {
  return nums.reduce((a, b) => a + b);
}

sum(1, 2, 3); // 6

## 8. Anonymous Functions

Functions without a name, often used inline.

```js
setTimeout(function () {
  console.log("Delayed");
}, 1000);

docs.title: 9. Callback Functions
docs.text:
Function passed as an argument to another function.

function process(data, callback) {
  callback(data);
}

process(5, function (num) {
  console.log(num * 2);
});

docs.title: Strings
docs.text: Strings represent text and are one of the most commonly used data types in JavaScript.

docs.title: 1. Creating Strings
docs.text:
let str1 = "Hello";
let str2 = 'World';
let str3 = `Hello, ${str2}`; // Template literal

docs.title: 2. String Length
docs.text:
let name = "John";
console.log(name.length); // 4

docs.title: 3. Accessing Characters
docs.text:
let str = "JavaScript";
console.log(str[0]);      // "J"
console.log(str.charAt(2)); // "v"

docs.title: toUpperCase() / toLowerCase()
docs.text:
"abc".toUpperCase(); // "ABC"
"XYZ".toLowerCase(); // "xyz"

docs.title: indexOf() / lastIndexOf()
docs.text:
"hello".indexOf("l");      // 2
"hello".lastIndexOf("l");  // 3

docs.title: includes()
docs.text: "hello".includes("he"); // true

docs.title: startsWith() / endsWith()
docs.text:
"hello".startsWith("he"); // true
"hello".endsWith("lo");   // true

docs.title: slice(start, end)
docs.text: "JavaScript".slice(0, 4); // "Java"

docs.title: substring(start, end)
docs.text: "JavaScript".substring(4, 10); // "Script"

docs.title: substr(start, length) (deprecated)
docs.text: "JavaScript".substr(4, 3); // "Scr"

docs.title: replace() / replaceAll()
docs.text:
"apple pie".replace("pie", "juice"); // "apple juice"
"aaa".replaceAll("a", "b"); // "bbb"

docs.title: trim(), trimStart(), trimEnd()
docs.text: "  hello  ".trim(); // "hello"

docs.title: split()
docs.text: "red,green,blue".split(","); // ["red", "green", "blue"]

docs.title: repeat(n)
docs.text: "ha".repeat(3); // "hahaha"

docs.title: 5. Template Literals
docs.text:
Use backticks ` for multiline and interpolation.

let name = "Alice";
let msg = `Hello, ${name}!`;

docs.title: 6. Escape Characters
docs.text:
let str = "He said: \"Hello\"";
let path = "C:\\Users\\User";

docs.title: 7. Comparing Strings
docs.text:
"abc" === "abc"; // true
"abc" > "abd";   // false (lexical order)

docs.title: Arrays
docs.text: Arrays are ordered lists used to store multiple values in a single variable. They can contain any data type — strings, numbers, objects, functions, etc.

docs.title: 1. Creating Arrays
docs.text:
let arr = [10, 20, 30];
let empty = new Array(); // []

docs.title: 2. Accessing Items
docs.text:
arr[0];     // 10
arr.length; // 3
arr[arr.length - 1]; // Last item

docs.title: 3. Modifying Items
docs.text:
arr[1] = 99;       // [10, 99, 30]
arr.push(40);      // [10, 99, 30, 40]
arr.pop();         // Removes last → [10, 99, 30]
arr.shift();       // Removes first → [99, 30]
arr.unshift(5);    // Adds to front → [5, 99, 30]

docs.title: push() / pop()
docs.text:
arr.push(100); // add to end
arr.pop();     // remove from end

docs.title: shift() / unshift()
docs.text:
arr.shift();     // remove first
arr.unshift(0);  // add to start

docs.title: slice(start, end)
docs.text:
Returns a shallow copy of a portion.

let sliced = arr.slice(1, 3); // [99, 30]

docs.title: splice(start, deleteCount, ...items)
docs.text:
Modifies the array (insert/remove/replace).

arr.splice(1, 1);         // Remove 1 item at index 1
arr.splice(1, 0, 88);     // Insert 88 at index 1

docs.title: indexOf() / includes()
docs.text:
arr.indexOf(30);   // 2
arr.includes(99);  // true

docs.title: join()
docs.text: arr.join(", "); // "5, 99, 30"

docs.title: reverse()
docs.text: arr.reverse(); // In-place reverse

docs.title: sort()
docs.text:
arr.sort(); // Lexicographic sort
arr.sort((a, b) => a - b); // Numeric sort

docs.title: for loop
docs.text:
for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {
  console.log(arr[i]);
}

docs.title: for...of
docs.text:
for (let val of arr) {
  console.log(val);
}

docs.title: forEach()
docs.text:
arr.forEach((val, i) => {
  console.log(i, val);
});

docs.title: map()
docs.text: let doubled = arr.map(n => n * 2);

docs.title: filter()
docs.text: let evens = arr.filter(n => n % 2 === 0);

docs.title: reduce()
docs.text: let sum = arr.reduce((acc, curr) => acc + curr, 0);

docs.title: 7. Nested Arrays
docs.text:
let grid = [[1, 2], [3, 4]];
console.log(grid[1][0]); // 3

docs.title: 1. What Is the DOM?
docs.text:
DOM (Document Object Model) is a tree-like structure where:

  • Each HTML element is a node
  • JavaScript can access and manipulate these nodes

The root is document.

docs.title: 2. Accessing the Document
docs.text:
console.log(document);           // entire DOM
console.log(document.title);     // page title
console.log(document.body);      // <body> element

docs.title: a) getElementById
docs.text:
Selects a single element by ID.

let heading = document.getElementById("main-title");

docs.title: b) getElementsByClassName
docs.text:
Returns a live HTMLCollection (not an array).

let items = document.getElementsByClassName("menu-item");

Access with index: items[0]

docs.title: c) getElementsByTagName
docs.text:
Returns all elements by tag name.

let allParas = document.getElementsByTagName("p");

docs.title: querySelector
docs.text:
Returns first match using CSS selector.

let btn = document.querySelector(".btn");       // first .btn
let header = document.querySelector("#header"); // #header
let input = document.querySelector("input[type='text']");

docs.title: querySelectorAll
docs.text:
Returns NodeList of all matches.

let allButtons = document.querySelectorAll(".btn");

Loop with forEach():

allButtons.forEach(btn => btn.classList.add("active"));

docs.title: 5. NodeList vs HTMLCollection
docs.text:
Feature NodeList HTMLCollection Returned by querySelectorAll getElementsBy* Can use forEach() ✅ (modern browsers) ❌ (convert to array) Live updates ❌ static ✅ live

To convert HTMLCollection:

Array.from(items).forEach(el => console.log(el));

docs.title: innerText
docs.text:
Returns visible text.

element.innerText = "Hello";

docs.title: textContent
docs.text:
Returns all text, including hidden.

element.textContent = "Hi";

docs.title: innerHTML
docs.text:
Reads or replaces the HTML inside an element.

element.innerHTML = "<strong>Bold text</strong>";

docs.title: 2. Changing Styles
docs.text:
Use .style.propertyName (camelCase for CSS).

element.style.color = "red";
element.style.backgroundColor = "#f0f0f0";

docs.title: add() – Add a class
docs.text: element.classList.add("active");

docs.title: remove() – Remove a class
docs.text: element.classList.remove("disabled");

docs.title: toggle() – Add if missing, remove if present
docs.text: element.classList.toggle("open");

docs.title: contains() – Check if class exists
docs.text: element.classList.contains("active"); // true/false

docs.title: getAttribute()
docs.text: let link = element.getAttribute("href");

docs.title: setAttribute()
docs.text: element.setAttribute("src", "img.png");

docs.title: removeAttribute()
docs.text: element.removeAttribute("disabled");

docs.title: 5. Input Values
docs.text:
Use .value for form elements.

let input = document.querySelector("#username");
console.log(input.value);       // get
input.value = "newUser123";     // set

docs.title: 6. Example: Modify Button Text & Style
docs.text:
let btn = document.querySelector("#submit");

btn.innerText = "Sending...";
btn.style.backgroundColor = "gray";
btn.classList.add("disabled");

docs.title: 1. createElement()
docs.text:
Creates a new DOM element (not in the document yet).

let newDiv = document.createElement("div");
newDiv.innerText = "Hello World";

docs.title: 2. append() and appendChild()
docs.text:
Adds element to the end of a parent.

document.body.append(newDiv);       // accepts text, multiple elements
parent.appendChild(newDiv);         // older, only one node

docs.title: prepend()
docs.text:
Adds to the start of a parent.

parent.prepend(newDiv);

docs.title: 3. insertBefore()
docs.text:
Inserts a node before another inside the same parent.

parent.insertBefore(newNode, referenceNode);

docs.title: 4. remove() (modern)
docs.text:
Removes an element directly.

element.remove();

docs.title: 5. removeChild() (older)
docs.text:
Used on the parent, passing the child to remove.

parent.removeChild(child);

docs.title: 6. replaceChild()
docs.text:
Replaces one child with another.

parent.replaceChild(newNode, oldNode);

docs.title: cloneNode(deep)
docs.text:
• true → clone entire element with children
  • false → only clone the node itself
let clone = original.cloneNode(true);
parent.append(clone);

docs.title: 8. Example: Add New List Item
docs.text:
let li = document.createElement("li");
li.innerText = "New Item";

document.querySelector("ul").appendChild(li);

docs.title: 1. What Are Events?
docs.text: Events are actions that happen in the browser (click, scroll, keypress, input, etc.). You can run functions in response.

docs.title: 2. addEventListener()
docs.text:
Attach a function to run when an event occurs.

element.addEventListener("click", function () {
  console.log("Clicked");
});

docs.title: Common events:
docs.text:
• click
  • mouseover / mouseout
  • keydown / keyup
  • input
  • submit
  • change

docs.title: 3. Named Function Example
docs.text:
function greet() {
  console.log("Hello");
}

button.addEventListener("click", greet);

docs.title: 4. Arrow Function Example
docs.text:
button.addEventListener("click", () => {
  console.log("Clicked!");
});

docs.title: 5. Accessing the Event Object
docs.text:
Every event listener gets an event object with info about the action.

element.addEventListener("click", function (event) {
  console.log(event.target); // the element that was clicked
});

docs.title: 6. Prevent Default Behavior
docs.text:
Use event.preventDefault() to stop default actions like form submit or link navigation.

form.addEventListener("submit", function (e) {
  e.preventDefault();
  console.log("Form blocked");
});

docs.title: 7. Event Delegation
docs.text:
Listen to a parent and handle clicks from child elements using event.target.

document.querySelector("ul").addEventListener("click", function (e) {
  if (e.target.tagName === "LI") {
    e.target.classList.toggle("selected");
  }
});

docs.title: 8. Removing Event Listeners
docs.text:
function handler() {
  console.log("Removed after one use");
  btn.removeEventListener("click", handler);
}

btn.addEventListener("click", handler);

docs.title: 9. once Option
docs.text:
Automatically removes listener after first trigger.

btn.addEventListener("click", () => {
  console.log("Clicked once");
}, { once: true });

docs.title: Callbacks
docs.text: A callback is a function passed as an argument to another function, to be called later — either after an operation completes or at a specific time.

docs.title: 1. Basic Callback Example
docs.text:
function greet(name) {
  console.log("Hello, " + name);
}

function processUser(callback) {
  let name = "Alice";
  callback(name);
}

processUser(greet); // "Hello, Alice"

docs.title: 2. Anonymous Callback
docs.text:
setTimeout(function () {
  console.log("Executed after 1 second");
}, 1000);

docs.title: 3. Arrow Function Callback
docs.text:
setTimeout(() => {
  console.log("Arrow callback");
}, 500);

docs.title: forEach
docs.text:
[1, 2, 3].forEach(num => {
  console.log(num);
});

docs.title: map
docs.text: let doubled = [1, 2, 3].map(n => n * 2);

docs.title: filter
docs.text: let even = [1, 2, 3, 4].filter(n => n % 2 === 0);

docs.title: 5. Why Use Callbacks?
docs.text:
• Handle asynchronous tasks (API calls, timeouts)
  • Reuse logic
  • Custom behavior passed into functions

docs.title: 6. Callback Hell (Bad Practice)
docs.text:
Nested callbacks make code hard to read:

doTask1(() => {
  doTask2(() => {
    doTask3(() => {
      console.log("Done");
    });
  });
});

Use Promises or async/await to fix this.

docs.title: Promises
docs.text: A Promise is an object representing the eventual result of an asynchronous operation — it may resolve (success) or reject (failure).

docs.title: 1. Creating a Promise
docs.text:
const promise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  let success = true;

  if (success) {
    resolve("Done");
  } else {
    reject("Error");
  }
});

docs.title: 2. Consuming a Promise
docs.text:
promise
  .then(result => {
    console.log("Resolved:", result);
  })
  .catch(error => {
    console.log("Rejected:", error);
  });

docs.title: 3. Example: Simulated Async Task
docs.text:
function asyncTask() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => {
      resolve("Task complete");
    }, 1000);
  });
}

asyncTask().then(res => console.log(res));

docs.title: 4. Chaining Promises
docs.text:
doStep1()
  .then(result1 => doStep2(result1))
  .then(result2 => doStep3(result2))
  .then(final => console.log("Final:", final))
  .catch(err => console.error(err));

docs.title: 5. Promise.all([])
docs.text:
Runs multiple promises in parallel, waits for all.

Promise.all([p1, p2, p3])
  .then(values => console.log(values))
  .catch(err => console.log(err));

docs.title: 6. Promise.race([])
docs.text:
Returns the result of the first resolved/rejected promise.

Promise.race([p1, p2])
  .then(result => console.log("First done:", result));

docs.title: 7. Promise States
docs.text: State Description pending Initial state, neither done nor failed fulfilled Operation completed successfully rejected Operation failed

docs.title: 8. When to Use Promises
docs.text:
• API calls (fetch)
  • File reading
  • Delayed actions
  • Replacing deeply nested callbacks (callback hell)

Use async/await for cleaner syntax (covered next).

docs.title: async/await
docs.text: async and await are syntactic sugar over Promises that make asynchronous code look and behave like synchronous code.

docs.title: 1. async Function
docs.text:
Declaring a function async makes it return a Promise.

async function greet() {
  return "Hello";
}

greet().then(msg => console.log(msg)); // "Hello"

docs.title: 2. await
docs.text:
await pauses the function until the Promise resolves.

async function loadData() {
  let response = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data");
  let data = await response.json();
  console.log(data);
}
  • Can only use await inside an async function
  • It waits for the Promise to resolve

docs.title: 3. Try/Catch for Error Handling
docs.text:
Use try/catch to handle rejections.

async function getUser() {
  try {
    let res = await fetch("https://api.example.com/user");
    let user = await res.json();
    console.log(user);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Failed:", err);
  }
}

docs.title: 4. Parallel await with Promise.all
docs.text:
async function loadAll() {
  const [res1, res2] = await Promise.all([
    fetch("/api/one"),
    fetch("/api/two")
  ]);
  const data1 = await res1.json();
  const data2 = await res2.json();
}

docs.title: 5. Invalid Usage (Don't Do This)
docs.text: await fetch("/url"); // ❌ SyntaxError: await is only valid in async functions

docs.title: 6. When to Use
docs.text:
Use async/await for:

  • Cleaner, readable async logic
  • Avoiding .then() chains
  • Fetching API data
  • Sequencing dependent async operations

docs.title: try...catch & Error Handling
docs.text: try...catch is used to safely handle errors in synchronous and asynchronous code, preventing crashes and allowing custom responses.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
try {
  // Code that might throw an error
} catch (err) {
  // Runs if error occurs
}

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
try {
  let x = y + 1; // y is not defined → error
} catch (err) {
  console.log("Error caught:", err.message);
}

docs.title: 2. finally Block
docs.text:
Always runs, whether error occurs or not.

try {
  // risky code
} catch (err) {
  console.log("Handled error");
} finally {
  console.log("This always runs");
}

docs.title: 3. Error Object
docs.text:
In catch(err), the err object contains:

  • name: error type (e.g. ReferenceError)
  • message: description
  • stack: call trace (for debugging)
try {
  throw new Error("Something went wrong");
} catch (e) {
  console.log(e.name);    // Error
  console.log(e.message); // Something went wrong
}

docs.title: 4. Handling Errors in Functions
docs.text:
function divide(a, b) {
  if (b === 0) throw new Error("Cannot divide by zero");
  return a / b;
}

try {
  console.log(divide(10, 0));
} catch (err) {
  console.log("Math error:", err.message);
}

docs.title: 5. Async + try/catch
docs.text:
Always wrap await calls in try/catch.

async function fetchData() {
  try {
    let res = await fetch("invalid-url");
    let data = await res.json();
  } catch (err) {
    console.log("Fetch failed:", err.message);
  }
}

docs.title: 6. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use try/catch around isolated risky logic
  • Don’t overuse — handle only expected errors
  • Use finally for cleanup tasks (e.g. closing connections, hiding loaders)
  • Throw custom errors to improve debugging and user messages

docs.title: Classes & Objects
docs.text: JavaScript supports object-oriented programming (OOP) using classes (ES6+) and constructor functions. Classes help organize related data and behavior into reusable blueprints.

docs.title: 1. Creating a Class
docs.text:
class Person {
  constructor(name, age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
  }

  greet() {
    console.log(`Hi, I'm ${this.name}`);
  }
}

docs.title: 2. Creating Objects (Instances)
docs.text:
const user1 = new Person("Alice", 25);
user1.greet(); // Hi, I'm Alice

docs.title: 3. Constructor Method
docs.text:
• constructor() is called automatically when using new
  • Used to initialize object properties
class Car {
  constructor(brand, year) {
    this.brand = brand;
    this.year = year;
  }
}

docs.title: 4. Adding Methods
docs.text:
Define methods directly inside the class:

class Circle {
  constructor(radius) {
    this.radius = radius;
  }

  area() {
    return Math.PI * this.radius ** 2;
  }
}

docs.title: 5. Class Expression (Anonymous or Named)
docs.text:
const Animal = class {
  constructor(type) {
    this.type = type;
  }
};

docs.title: 6. Inheritance (extends)
docs.text:
One class can inherit from another.

class Animal {
  speak() {
    console.log("Generic sound");
  }
}

class Dog extends Animal {
  speak() {
    console.log("Bark");
  }
}

const d = new Dog();
d.speak(); // Bark

docs.title: 7. super() Keyword
docs.text:
Calls the constructor or method from the parent class.

class Animal {
  constructor(name) {
    this.name = name;
  }
}

class Cat extends Animal {
  constructor(name, color) {
    super(name);
    this.color = color;
  }
}

docs.title: 8. Static Methods
docs.text:
Static methods belong to the class, not instances.

class MathUtil {
  static square(x) {
    return x * x;
  }
}

MathUtil.square(4); // 16

docs.title: 9. Object vs Class
docs.text:
• Object literal: used for single instances
  • Class: used for creating multiple objects with shared structure
// Object literal
const user = {
  name: "Bob",
  greet() {
    console.log("Hi");
  }
};

Use object literals for simple structures, classes for reusable templates.

docs.title: Fetch API
docs.text: The Fetch API is used to make HTTP requests (GET, POST, etc.) from the browser. It returns a Promise.

docs.title: 1. Basic GET Request
docs.text:
fetch("https://api.example.com/data")
  .then(res => res.json())
  .then(data => {
    console.log(data);
  })
  .catch(err => {
    console.error("Fetch error:", err);
  });
  • res.json() parses JSON response
  • Always use .catch() to handle network errors

docs.title: 2. Using async/await
docs.text:
async function getData() {
  try {
    const res = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data");
    const data = await res.json();
    console.log(data);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Error:", err);
  }
}

docs.title: 3. POST Request (Sending Data)
docs.text:
fetch("https://api.example.com/users", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: {
    "Content-Type": "application/json"
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({
    name: "Alice",
    age: 25
  })
})
  .then(res => res.json())
  .then(data => console.log(data))
  .catch(err => console.error(err));

docs.title: 4. Common Options
docs.text: Option Description method HTTP method (GET, POST, etc.) headers HTTP headers (e.g. Content-Type) body Payload (for POST, PUT) mode CORS control (cors, no-cors) credentials same-origin, include

docs.title: 5. Handling Errors Manually
docs.text:
Even if the response is 404/500, fetch() doesn’t throw — you must check res.ok.

async function getUser() {
  const res = await fetch("/api/user");

  if (!res.ok) {
    throw new Error(`HTTP error ${res.status}`);
  }

  const data = await res.json();
  console.log(data);
}

docs.title: 6. Sending Form Data (Non-JSON)
docs.text:
const formData = new FormData();
formData.append("username", "john");
formData.append("age", 30);

fetch("/submit", {
  method: "POST",
  body: formData
});

Use FormData when submitting forms without setting headers manually.

docs.title: 7. Abort a Request
docs.text:
const controller = new AbortController();

fetch("/api/data", { signal: controller.signal })
  .catch(err => console.error("Aborted"));

controller.abort(); // cancel the request

docs.title: What is MongoDB?
docs.text: MongoDB is a NoSQL (non-relational) database that stores data in a document-oriented format using JSON-like objects called BSON (Binary JSON). Unlike traditional relational databases that use tables and rows, MongoDB uses collections and documents.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Document-Oriented Storage – Data is stored in flexible, schema-less JSON-like documents.
  • Scalability – Supports horizontal scaling using sharding.
  • High Performance – Optimized for read and write operations.
  • Indexing – Supports various types of indexes to improve query performance.
  • Aggregation Framework – Used to process data and perform operations like filtering, grouping, and sorting.
  • Replication – Provides high availability using replica sets.

docs.title: Basic Terminology
docs.text:
• Database – A container for collections.
  • Collection – A group of related documents (similar to a table in SQL).
  • Document – A single record in MongoDB stored as a BSON object.
  • Field – A key-value pair inside a document (similar to a column).
  • _id – A unique identifier automatically generated for each document.

docs.title: Example Document
docs.text:
{
  "_id": 1,
  "name": "Rajesh Singh",
  "age": 25,
  "skills": ["HTML", "CSS", "JavaScript", "Python", "Node.js"]
}

docs.title: Comparison with SQL Databases
docs.text: SQL Database MongoDB Table Collection Row Document Column Field Primary Key _id Joins Embedded Documents / $lookup Schema Schema-less

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Flexible data structure (no need to define schema in advance)
  • Easy to scale horizontally
  • High speed for large-scale applications
  • JSON-like syntax makes it developer-friendly

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Real-time analytics
  • Content management systems
  • IoT and sensor data storage
  • E-commerce platforms
  • Social media applications

docs.title: Installation & Basic Commands
docs.text:
• Start MongoDB Shell:
mongosh
  • Show databases:
show dbs
  • Use or create a database:
use myDatabase
  • Show collections:
show collections
  • Insert a document:
db.users.insertOne({ name: "Harry", age: 22 })
  • Find documents:
db.users.find()

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: CRUD stands for Create, Read, Update, Delete - the four basic operations you can perform on a database. MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in JSON-like documents (BSON).

docs.title: Insert One Document
docs.text:
db.collectionName.insertOne({
    name: "Rahul",
    age: 16,
    city: "Delhi"
});

docs.title: Insert Many Documents
docs.text:
db.collectionName.insertMany([
    { name: "Ravi", age: 17, city: "Mumbai" },
    { name: "Sara", age: 15, city: "Bangalore" }
]);

docs.title: Find All Documents
docs.text: db.collectionName.find();

docs.title: Find One Document
docs.text: db.collectionName.findOne({ name: "Lily" });

docs.title: Find with Conditions
docs.text: db.collectionName.find({ age: { $gt: 15 } }); // age greater than 15

docs.title: Projection (Select Fields)
docs.text: db.collectionName.find({ age: { $gt: 15 } }, { name: 1, city: 1, _id: 0 });

docs.title: Update One Document
docs.text:
db.collectionName.updateOne(
    { name: "Piyush" },
    { $set: { city: "Noida" } }
);

docs.title: Update Many Documents
docs.text:
db.collectionName.updateMany(
    { age: { $lt: 17 } },
    { $set: { status: "minor" } }
);

docs.title: Replace a Document
docs.text:
db.collectionName.replaceOne(
    { name: "Sara" },
    { name: "Sara", age: 16, city: "Pune" }
);

docs.title: Delete One Document
docs.text: db.collectionName.deleteOne({ name: "Ravi" });

docs.title: Delete Many Documents
docs.text: db.collectionName.deleteMany({ age: { $lt: 16 } });

docs.title: 5. Common Operators
docs.text:
• $gt → Greater than
  • $lt → Less than
  • $gte → Greater than or equal
  • $lte → Less than or equal
  • $ne → Not equal
  • $in → Matches any value in an array
  • $nin → Matches none in an array
  • $set → Updates specified fields
  • $unset → Removes specified fields

docs.title: Example Flow
docs.text:
// 1. Create
db.students.insertOne({ name: "Chris", age: 16, grade: "10th" });

// 2. Read
db.students.find({ age: { $gte: 16 } });

// 3. Update
db.students.updateOne({ name: "Chris" }, { $set: { grade: "11th" } });

// 4. Delete
db.students.deleteOne({ name: "Chris" });

docs.title: Mongoose
docs.text: Mongoose is an Object Data Modeling (ODM) library for MongoDB and Node.js. It helps developers interact with MongoDB using JavaScript objects instead of writing raw database queries.

docs.title: Why Use Mongoose?
docs.text:
• Provides Schema-based data modeling.
  • Offers validation, middleware, and query helpers.
  • Handles relationships and data population.
  • Simplifies CRUD operations with a clean API.
  • Automatically converts JavaScript objects into MongoDB documents.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install mongoose

docs.title: Connecting to MongoDB
docs.text:
import mongoose from "mongoose";

async function connectDB() {
  try {
    await mongoose.connect("mongodb://localhost:27017/myDatabase");
    console.log("MongoDB connected!");
  } catch (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
}

connectDB();

docs.title: Defining a Schema
docs.text:
A schema defines the structure of documents within a collection.

const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: String,
  age: Number,
  email: { type: String, required: true, unique: true }
});

docs.title: Creating a Model
docs.text:
A model is a wrapper around a MongoDB collection that provides CRUD methods.

const User = mongoose.model("User", userSchema);

docs.title: 1. Create
docs.text:
const newUser = new User({ name: "Luke", age: 16, email: "Luke@example.com" });
await newUser.save();

docs.title: 2. Read
docs.text:
const users = await User.find(); // Get all users
const user = await User.findOne({ name: "Luke" }); // Find one
const userById = await User.findById("id_here"); // Find by ID

docs.title: 3. Update
docs.text:
await User.updateOne({ name: "Luke" }, { age: 17 });
await User.findByIdAndUpdate("id_here", { age: 18 }, { new: true });

docs.title: 4. Delete
docs.text:
await User.deleteOne({ name: "Luke" });
await User.findByIdAndDelete("id_here");

docs.title: Schema Types
docs.text:
Common field types:

String, Number, Boolean, Date, Array, ObjectId, Buffer

Example:

const postSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  title: String,
  content: String,
  tags: [String],
  author: { type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId, ref: "User" },
  date: { type: Date, default: Date.now }
});

docs.title: Schema Validation
docs.text:
const productSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: { type: String, required: true },
  price: { type: Number, min: 0 },
  inStock: { type: Boolean, default: true }
});

docs.title: Middleware (Hooks)
docs.text:
Run logic before or after actions like saving or deleting.

userSchema.pre("save", function (next) {
  console.log("Saving user:", this.name);
  next();
});

docs.title: Virtuals
docs.text:
Computed fields that are not stored in the database.

userSchema.virtual("info").get(function () {
  return `${this.name} (${this.age} years old)`;
});

docs.title: Populate (Relations)
docs.text:
Used to fetch related documents from another collection.

const post = await Post.find().populate("author");

docs.title: Example Project Structure
docs.text:
project/
├── models/
│   └── userModel.js
├── index.js
└── package.json
  • userModel.js
import mongoose from "mongoose";

const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: String,
  email: String,
  age: Number
});

export default mongoose.model("User", userSchema);
  • index.js
import mongoose from "mongoose";
import User from "./models/userModel.js";

await mongoose.connect("mongodb://localhost:27017/testDB");
const user = await User.create({ name: "Luke", email: "Luke@gmail.com", age: 16 });
console.log(user);

docs.title: What is Next.js?
docs.text: Next.js is a React-based framework developed by Vercel that simplifies building server-rendered and statically generated web applications. It enhances React by adding features like file-based routing, SSR (Server-Side Rendering), SSG (Static Site Generation), API routes, and optimized performance out of the box.

docs.title: Advantages of Next.js
docs.text:
• Improved SEO (thanks to SSR and SSG)
  • Faster page loading with pre-rendering
  • API routes (no separate backend needed for small apps)
  • Easy file-based routing system
  • Optimized images and static assets
  • Built-in TypeScript and ESLint support

docs.title: How to Create a Next.js App
docs.text:
1. Install using create-next-app:
npx create-next-app@latest my-next-app
  1. Run the development server:
cd my-next-app
npm run dev
  1. Open in browser: http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Typical Project Structure
docs.text:
my-app/
├── pages/
│   ├── index.js
│   ├── about.js
│   └── api/
│       └── hello.js
├── public/
│   └── images/
├── styles/
│   └── globals.css
├── next.config.js
└── package.json

docs.title: 1. File-Based Routing
docs.text:
• Each file inside the pages/ directory automatically becomes a route.
  • Example:
pages/
├── index.js        → '/'
├── about.js        → '/about'
└── blog/[id].js    → '/blog/:id'
  • No need to manually configure routes like in React Router.

docs.title: 2. Pre-rendering
docs.text: Next.js pre-renders every page by default, improving SEO and performance.

docs.title: Types of Pre-rendering:
docs.text:
• Static Generation (SSG) – HTML generated at build time.
export async function getStaticProps() {
  const data = await fetchData();
  return { props: { data } };
}
  • Server-Side Rendering (SSR) – HTML generated on each request.
export async function getServerSideProps() {
  const data = await fetchData();
  return { props: { data } };
}

docs.title: 3. Client-Side Rendering (CSR)
docs.text: Even though Next.js supports pre-rendering, you can still fetch data on the client side using React hooks like useEffect.

docs.title: 4. API Routes
docs.text:
You can create backend API endpoints inside the pages/api directory. Example:

// pages/api/hello.js
export default function handler(req, res) {
  res.status(200).json({ message: "Hello from API" });
}

docs.title: 5. Image Optimization
docs.text:
Next.js provides the <Image /> component for automatic image optimization:

import Image from "next/image";
<Image src="/profile.jpg" alt="Profile" width={200} height={200} />;

docs.title: 6. Built-in CSS and Sass Support
docs.text:
You can use:

  • Global CSS (in _app.js)
  • CSS Modules (.module.css)
  • Sass/SCSS files

Example:

import styles from "./Home.module.css";
function Home() {
  return <h1 className={styles.title}>Hello Next.js</h1>;
}

docs.title: 7. Middleware
docs.text:
Middleware runs before a request is completed — useful for authentication, redirects, or logging.

// middleware.js
export function middleware(req) {
  return NextResponse.redirect(new URL("/login", req.url));
}

docs.title: 8. Static File Serving
docs.text: Any files placed in the public/ directory can be accessed directly via URL. Example: public/image.png → accessible at http://localhost:3000/image.png

docs.title: 9. Deployment
docs.text: Next.js apps can be easily deployed on Vercel, the platform made by its creators, or any Node.js-compatible service (e.g., Netlify, AWS, etc.).

docs.title: Example: Basic Next.js Page
docs.text:
// pages/index.js
export default function Home() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Welcome to Next.js</h1>
      <p>This is your first Next.js page!</p>
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: What are Server Components?
docs.text:
Server Components are React components that are rendered on the server instead of the client. They allow you to fetch data, perform heavy computations, and render HTML directly on the server before sending it to the browser.

In Next.js (especially with the App Router), Server Components are the default type of components.

docs.title: Key Characteristics
docs.text:
• Executed on the Server: The code runs only on the server, never sent to the client.
  • No Client-Side JavaScript: Since they're not hydrated in the browser, bundle size is reduced.
  • Can Fetch Data Directly: You can use async/await for data fetching directly inside components.
  • Secure: Sensitive data (like API keys) stays on the server.

docs.title: Syntax Example
docs.text:
// app/page.js
import UserList from './UserList';

export default async function Page() {
  const data = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users');
  const users = await data.json();

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Users</h1>
      <UserList users={users} />
    </div>
  );
}

// app/UserList.js
export default function UserList({ users }) {
  return (
    <ul>
      {users.map(user => (
        <li key={user.id}>{user.name}</li>
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
}

Both components here are Server Components by default.

docs.title: Benefits of Server Components
docs.text:
1. Improved Performance

  2. Less JavaScript sent to the client → faster page loads.

  3. Direct Data Access

  4. No need for API routes or extra network calls between client and server.

  5. Better Security

  6. Secrets remain on the server.

  7. SEO-Friendly

  8. HTML is pre-rendered and easily indexed by search engines.

docs.title: When to Use Server Components
docs.text:
• When you need data fetching (e.g., from databases or APIs).
  • For static content or HTML-heavy components.
  • When you don’t need interactivity or client-side state.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Cannot use browser-only APIs (like window, document, or localStorage).
  • Cannot use React hooks like useState, useEffect.
  • Cannot attach event handlers (like onClick).

If you need any of these → use a Client Component.

docs.title: Mixing Server and Client Components
docs.text:
You can combine them for flexibility.

// app/page.js (Server Component)
import LikeButton from './LikeButton';

export default async function Page() {
  const post = await getPost();

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{post.title}</h1>
      <LikeButton /> {/* Client Component */}
    </div>
  );
}

// app/LikeButton.js (Client Component)
'use client';
import { useState } from 'react';

export default function LikeButton() {
  const [liked, setLiked] = useState(false);
  return <button onClick={() => setLiked(!liked)}>{liked ? 'Liked' : 'Like'}</button>;
}

docs.title: How Next.js Decides
docs.text:
• Files without 'use client' → Server Components (default).
  • Files with 'use client' → Client Components.

docs.title: Script, Link & Image components in Next.js
1. <Script> Component
docs.text: The <Script> component in Next.js is used to load third-party scripts (like analytics or ads) efficiently. It helps improve performance and control over when and how scripts are executed.

docs.title: Import
docs.text: import Script from "next/script";

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
<Script
  src="https://example.com/script.js"
  strategy="lazyOnload"
  onLoad={() => console.log("Script loaded!")}
/>

docs.title: Script Loading Strategies
docs.text: Strategy Description beforeInteractive Loads the script before the page becomes interactive. Useful for critical scripts. afterInteractive Default. Loads right after the page becomes interactive. lazyOnload Loads during idle time (after onload event). Ideal for analytics or tracking scripts. worker Loads script inside a web worker (for heavy scripts).

docs.title: Example with Google Analytics
docs.text:
<Script
  src="https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtag/js?id=GA_TRACKING_ID"
  strategy="afterInteractive"
/>
<Script id="google-analytics" strategy="afterInteractive">
  {`
    window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
    function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
    gtag('js', new Date());
    gtag('config', 'GA_TRACKING_ID');
  `}
</Script>

docs.title: 2. <Link> Component
docs.text: The <Link> component enables client-side navigation between pages — meaning page transitions are instant and don’t reload the browser.

docs.title: Import
docs.text: import Link from "next/link";

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
<Link href="/about">About Us</Link>

✅ No full page reload ✅ Preserves React state ✅ Prefetching enabled by default

docs.title: With Child Element
docs.text:
<Link href="/blog">
  <button>Go to Blog</button>
</Link>

docs.title: Prefetch
docs.text:
• Next.js automatically prefetches links when they are visible in the viewport.
  • To disable prefetch:
<Link href="/contact" prefetch={false}>
  Contact
</Link>

docs.title: 3. <Image> Component
docs.text: The <Image> component is used for optimized image loading, lazy loading, resizing, and format conversion automatically.

docs.title: Import
docs.text: import Image from "next/image";

docs.title: Example
docs.text: <Image src="/hero.jpg" alt="Hero Banner" width={800} height={400} priority />

docs.title: Key Props
docs.text: Prop Description src Image source (local or remote). alt Alt text for accessibility. width & height Required for layout and optimization. priority Preloads image for faster loading (good for hero images). fill Makes image fill its parent container using absolute positioning. sizes Defines responsive image sizes for different screen widths.

docs.title: Example: Responsive Image
docs.text:
<div className="relative w-[100%] h-[400px]">
  <Image
    src="/banner.jpg"
    alt="Banner"
    fill
    sizes="(max-width: 768px) 100vw, 50vw"
    style={{ objectFit: "cover" }}
  />
</div>

docs.title: Remote Images
docs.text:
Add domains in next.config.js:

module.exports = {
  images: {
    domains: ["example.com", "images.unsplash.com"],
  },
};

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Next.js allows you to create API routes as serverless functions that run on the server side. These routes are useful for handling backend logic such as authentication, database operations, form submissions, or third-party API integrations — all within the same Next.js app.

docs.title: Creating API Routes
docs.text: In Next.js (App Router), you define APIs inside the app/api directory.

docs.title: Example Structure
docs.text:
app/
 ├── api/
 │   └── hello/
 │       └── route.js

docs.title: Example: Basic API Route
docs.text:
// app/api/hello/route.js
export async function GET(request) {
  return Response.json({ message: "Hello from Next.js API!" });
}

Result: Visiting /api/hello will return:

{ "message": "Hello from Next.js API!" }

docs.title: Supported HTTP Methods
docs.text:
Next.js API routes can handle different HTTP methods:

export async function GET(request) {
  return Response.json({ message: "GET request received" });
}

export async function POST(request) {
  const data = await request.json();
  return Response.json({ message: "POST data received", data });
}

export async function PUT(request) {
  return Response.json({ message: "PUT request received" });
}

export async function DELETE(request) {
  return Response.json({ message: "DELETE request received" });
}

docs.title: Accessing Query Parameters
docs.text:
You can get URL parameters using request.url:

export async function GET(request) {
  const { searchParams } = new URL(request.url);
  const name = searchParams.get("name");
  return Response.json({ message: `Hello, ${name}` });
}

Example: /api/hello?name=Arjun → { "message": "Hello, Arjun" }

docs.title: Dynamic API Routes
docs.text: You can create dynamic routes using square brackets.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
app/api/users/[id]/route.js

export async function GET(request, { params }) {
  const { id } = params;
  return Response.json({ userId: id });
}

Access: /api/users/10 → { "userId": "10" }

docs.title: Handling JSON Input
docs.text:
For POST or PUT requests:

export async function POST(request) {
  const body = await request.json();
  return Response.json({ received: body });
}

Send Example (Frontend):

await fetch("/api/hello", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({ name: "Arjun" }),
});

docs.title: Using Middleware
docs.text:
You can add logic before sending responses:

export async function GET(request) {
  const auth = request.headers.get("authorization");
  if (auth !== "my-secret") {
    return Response.json({ error: "Unauthorized" }, { status: 401 });
  }
  return Response.json({ message: "Access granted" });
}

docs.title: API Routes vs. Server Actions
docs.text:
• API Routes: Used for traditional HTTP endpoints (like REST APIs).
  • Server Actions: Used for handling form submissions or direct server functions without API endpoints.

docs.title: Example: Fetching External APIs
docs.text:
export async function GET() {
  const res = await fetch("https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts");
  const posts = await res.json();
  return Response.json(posts);
}

docs.title: Folder Structure Summary
docs.text:
app/
 ├── api/
 │   ├── users/
 │   │   ├── route.js
 │   └── products/
 │       ├── route.js

Each folder inside app/api represents an endpoint. Example:

  • /api/users
  • /api/products

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• APIs run only on the server, never in the client bundle.
  • You can use databases, environment variables, and server-side packages safely inside API routes.
  • Response.json() is the recommended way to return data.

docs.title: What Are Server Actions?
docs.text:
Server Actions are functions that run on the server in Next.js, allowing you to mutate data, perform secure operations, and handle form submissions or server logic directly from components.

They are part of the React Server Components (RSC) architecture and introduced in Next.js 13.4+ with the App Router.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Run only on the server, never in the browser.
  • Allow form submissions without API routes.
  • Directly access databases, files, and environment variables.
  • Reduce boilerplate by avoiding separate /api endpoints.
  • Can be imported and used in Server Components and Client Components (with form submission).

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
1. No need for /api routes for simple CRUD operations
  2. Automatically handled security - runs server-side only
  3. Reduces client-side JavaScript bundle size
  4. Great for form handling and database mutations

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
1. Must be async functions
  2. Cannot run client-side logic or access browser APIs
  3. Must use "use server" directive
  4. Limited to App Router (not supported in Pages Router)

docs.title: 1. Define a Server Action
docs.text:
You declare a server action by adding "use server" at the top of a function:

"use server";

export async function addTodo(formData) {
  const title = formData.get("title");
  // Example: save to database
  await db.todo.create({ data: { title } });
}

docs.title: 2. Use with Forms
docs.text:
Server Actions can be directly connected to a <form> element using the action attribute:

<form action={addTodo}>
  <input type="text" name="title" placeholder="Enter todo" />
  <button type="submit">Add</button>
</form>

When the form is submitted:

  • The browser automatically sends data to the server.
  • The addTodo() server action executes on the server.
  • The page re-renders with updated data (if applicable).

docs.title: 3. Use Inside Server Components
docs.text:
You can call server actions in server components (e.g., for fetching or mutating data):

import { revalidatePath } from "next/cache";
import { addTodo } from "./actions";

export default async function TodoForm() {
  async function handleAdd(formData) {
    "use server";
    const title = formData.get("title");
    await db.todo.create({ data: { title } });
    revalidatePath("/todos"); // revalidate page after mutation
  }

  return (
    <form action={handleAdd}>
      <input name="title" />
      <button type="submit">Add Todo</button>
    </form>
  );
}

docs.title: 4. Use in Client Components
docs.text:
If you want to call a Server Action from a Client Component, you can import it and call it indirectly, but not directly (since it's server-only).

Example:

"use client";
import { addTodo } from "../actions/todoActions";

export default function AddTodoClient() {
  const handleClick = async () => {
    const formData = new FormData();
    formData.append("title", "Learn Next.js");
    await addTodo(formData);
  };

  return <button onClick={handleClick}>Add Todo</button>;
}

Next.js automatically handles calling the action on the server.

docs.title: Revalidation and Cache
docs.text:
Server Actions integrate with Next.js caching:

  • Use revalidatePath("/path") to re-render a page after data changes.
  • Use revalidateTag("tag") if using tag-based caching.

Example:

import { revalidatePath } from "next/cache";

("use server");

export async function deleteTodo(id) {
  await db.todo.delete({ where: { id } });
  revalidatePath("/todos");
}

docs.title: What is Middleware?
docs.text:
Middleware in Next.js is a special function that runs before a request is completed. It allows you to modify the request or response, redirect, or conditionally render content before reaching a page or API route.

Middleware runs on the Edge Runtime, meaning it executes closer to the user — resulting in faster performance.

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Authentication and access control
  • Redirects and rewrites
  • Logging and analytics
  • Localization (e.g., redirecting users based on language or region)
  • Feature flags or A/B testing

docs.title: File Location and Naming
docs.text: Middleware is defined in a file named middleware.js or middleware.ts, placed in the root of your project or inside the src/ directory (if you’re using one).

docs.title: Basic Example
docs.text:
// middleware.js
import { NextResponse } from "next/server";

export function middleware(request) {
  const url = request.nextUrl.clone();

  // Example: redirect user if not logged in
  const isLoggedIn = request.cookies.get("token");

  if (!isLoggedIn && url.pathname.startsWith("/dashboard")) {
    url.pathname = "/login";
    return NextResponse.redirect(url);
  }

  return NextResponse.next();
}

docs.title: Matching Paths (Configuration)
docs.text:
You can control where middleware runs using the config.matcher property.

export const config = {
  matcher: ["/dashboard/:path*", "/profile/:path*"],
};
  • /dashboard/:path* → applies to all subpaths under /dashboard
  • /about → applies only to /about

docs.title: Redirects Example
docs.text:
import { NextResponse } from "next/server";

export function middleware(request) {
  const url = request.nextUrl.clone();

  if (url.pathname === "/") {
    url.pathname = "/home";
    return NextResponse.redirect(url);
  }

  return NextResponse.next();
}

docs.title: Rewriting Example
docs.text:
Rewriting lets you serve content from a different path without changing the URL.

import { NextResponse } from "next/server";

export function middleware(request) {
  if (request.nextUrl.pathname === "/old-page") {
    return NextResponse.rewrite(new URL("/new-page", request.url));
  }
}

docs.title: Conditional Headers Example
docs.text:
You can modify headers in requests or responses:

import { NextResponse } from "next/server";

export function middleware(request) {
  const response = NextResponse.next();
  response.headers.set("X-Custom-Header", "EdgeMiddleware");
  return response;
}

docs.title: Middleware Execution Order
docs.text:
1. The middleware runs before the request is processed.
  2. If the middleware modifies or redirects, it affects what the user receives.
  3. If not, it passes control to the requested page or API route.

docs.title: Edge Runtime Limitations
docs.text:
Middleware runs on the Edge Runtime, which:

  • Does not support Node.js APIs like fs, path, or process.
  • Supports Web APIs such as fetch, URL, and Request.

docs.title: What is Auth.js?
docs.text: Auth.js (formerly known as NextAuth.js) is a flexible and secure authentication solution for Next.js applications. It supports multiple authentication methods — OAuth providers, Credentials, Email, and more — and integrates seamlessly with Next.js App Router (v13+).

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Simple integration with App Router and API routes
  • Supports OAuth, Credentials, Magic Links, Email, and WebAuthn
  • Built-in support for databases (PostgreSQL, MongoDB, etc.)
  • JWT and Session-based authentication
  • Highly customizable with callbacks, events, and adapters
  • Compatible with TypeScript

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: npm install next-auth

docs.title: Folder Structure (App Router)
docs.text:
/app
  /api
    /auth
      [...nextauth]
        /route.js
  /dashboard
    page.js
  /login
    page.js

docs.title: 1. Create the Auth Route
docs.text:
File: /app/api/auth/[...nextauth]/route.js

import NextAuth from "next-auth";
import GoogleProvider from "next-auth/providers/google";

export const authOptions = {
  providers: [
    GoogleProvider({
      clientId: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID,
      clientSecret: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET,
    }),
  ],
  secret: process.env.NEXTAUTH_SECRET,
};

const handler = NextAuth(authOptions);
export { handler as GET, handler as POST };

docs.title: 2. Add Auth.js Client in Components
docs.text:
You can use NextAuth React Hooks to handle login and logout.

npm install next-auth @auth/react

Then wrap your app with the provider.

File: /app/layout.js

import { SessionProvider } from "next-auth/react";

export default function RootLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <body>
        <SessionProvider>{children}</SessionProvider>
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}

docs.title: 3. Sign In / Sign Out Buttons
docs.text:
"use client";
import { signIn, signOut, useSession } from "next-auth/react";

export default function AuthButton() {
  const { data: session } = useSession();

  if (session) {
    return (
      <>
        <p>Signed in as {session.user.email}</p>
        <button onClick={() => signOut()}>Sign out</button>
      </>
    );
  }
  return <button onClick={() => signIn("google")}>Sign in with Google</button>;
}

docs.title: Securing Pages
docs.text: You can protect server components or routes using getServerSession().

docs.title: Example: Protected Page
docs.text:
import { getServerSession } from "next-auth";
import { authOptions } from "../api/auth/[...nextauth]/route";

export default async function Dashboard() {
  const session = await getServerSession(authOptions);

  if (!session) {
    return <p>Access Denied</p>;
  }

  return <h1>Welcome, {session.user.name}</h1>;
}

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text:
Auth.js supports many providers out of the box:

  • Google
  • GitHub
  • Facebook
  • Discord
  • Twitter
  • Auth0
  • Apple
  • Credentials (Custom username/password)
  • Email (Magic link)

Example (Credentials Provider):

import CredentialsProvider from "next-auth/providers/credentials";

providers: [
  CredentialsProvider({
    name: "Credentials",
    credentials: {
      username: { label: "Username", type: "text" },
      password: { label: "Password", type: "password" },
    },
    async authorize(credentials) {
      const user = { id: 1, name: "Admin", email: "admin@example.com" };
      if (credentials.username === "admin" && credentials.password === "1234") {
        return user;
      }
      return null;
    },
  }),
];

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text: You can access session data from both server and client:

docs.title: Client Side
docs.text:
import { useSession } from "next-auth/react";

const { data: session } = useSession();

docs.title: Server Side
docs.text:
import { getServerSession } from "next-auth";

const session = await getServerSession();

docs.title: Database Integration (Optional)
docs.text:
Auth.js can store users, sessions, and tokens in a database using Adapters.

Example for Prisma:

npm install @auth/prisma-adapter @prisma/client

import { PrismaAdapter } from "@auth/prisma-adapter";
import { PrismaClient } from "@prisma/client";
const prisma = new PrismaClient();

export const authOptions = {
  adapter: PrismaAdapter(prisma),
  providers: [
    /* ... */
  ],
};

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set these in .env.local:

GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret
NEXTAUTH_URL=http://localhost:3000
NEXTAUTH_SECRET=your_random_secret

docs.title: Middleware for Route Protection
docs.text:
You can protect routes using middleware: File: /middleware.js

export { default } from "next-auth/middleware";

export const config = {
  matcher: ["/dashboard/:path*"],
};

docs.title: What are Dynamic Routes
docs.text:
Dynamic routes let you create pages where part of the URL is variable. For example:

  • /products/1
  • /products/2
  • /blog/how-to-code
  • /user/steve

These routes share the same page structure but show different data.

docs.title: How to Create a Dynamic Route
docs.text:
Use square brackets for the file or folder name.

Example:

app/
  blog/
    [slug]/
      page.js

This makes /blog/something work.

Another example:

app/
  product/
    [id]/
      page.js

This makes /product/123 work.

docs.title: Accessing Route Params
docs.text:
In the App Router (Next.js 13+):

export default function Page({ params }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Product ID: {params.id}</h1>
    </div>
  )
}

params.id is the dynamic value from the URL.

docs.title: Multiple Dynamic Segments
docs.text:
Example:

app/
  blog/
    [year]/
      [slug]/
        page.js

Gives URLs like: /blog/2025/nextjs-routing

Access:

export default function Page({ params }) {
  const { year, slug } = params
}

docs.title: Catch All Routes
docs.text: Sometimes you need to match any depth.

docs.title: Catch-all:
docs.text:
app/docs/[...slug]/page.js

URL examples:

  • /docs/getting-started
  • /docs/guides/install/setup

params.slug becomes an array.

docs.title: Optional Catch-all:
docs.text:
app/docs/[[...slug]]/page.js

Matches:

  • /docs
  • /docs/a
  • /docs/a/b

docs.title: Dynamic API Routes
docs.text:
In app/api or pages/api:

app/api/user/[id]/route.js

Access:

export async function GET(req, { params }) {
  return Response.json({ id: params.id })
}

docs.title: Pre-rendering with generateStaticParams
docs.text:
For static site generation:

export async function generateStaticParams() {
  return [
    { id: "1" },
    { id: "2" }
  ]
}

docs.title: What is a Layout
docs.text: A layout is a shared UI wrapper that surrounds your pages and components. It stays persistent across route changes and prevents unnecessary re-renders. Located at: app/layout.js or any route’s layout.js.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Persistent components across navigation
  • Automatic nested layouts
  • Server components by default
  • Can fetch data
  • Perfect for shared UI: navbars, sidebars, footers, providers

docs.title: Root Layout
docs.text:
File: app/layout.js

  • Required for every Next.js app
  • Defines HTML structure, <html>, <body>
  • Wraps the entire app

Example:

// app/layout.js
export const metadata = {
  title: "My App"
}

export default function RootLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <body>
        <Navbar />
        {children}
      </body>
    </html>
  )
}

docs.title: Nested Layouts
docs.text:
Each folder inside app/ can have its own layout.js.

Folder structure:

app/
 ├ layout.js
 ├ dashboard/
 │   ├ layout.js
 │   └ page.js
 └ settings/
     └ page.js

How it works:

  • app/layout.js wraps everything
  • app/dashboard/layout.js wraps only /dashboard and its children

Nested example:

// app/dashboard/layout.js
export default function DashboardLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <section>
      <aside>Dashboard Sidebar</aside>
      <main>{children}</main>
    </section>
  )
}

docs.title: Rendering Behavior
docs.text:
• Layouts are Server Components unless you add "use client"
  • They persist across route changes
  • Only the children part updates
  • This improves performance and UX

docs.title: Shared UI Patterns
docs.text:
Layouts are perfect for:

  • Navbars
  • Footers
  • Sidebars
  • Page containers
  • Themes
  • Global Providers (wrapped inside body)

docs.title: Layout vs Template
docs.text: Feature Layout Template Persistence Persistent across navigation Re-rendered on each route Use case Headers, navbars, providers Per-page animations or state reset Lifecycle Only rendered once Rendered every time route changes

docs.title: Example Layout with Providers
docs.text:
// app/layout.js
import { ThemeProvider } from "@/components/theme-provider"

export default function RootLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <html>
      <body>
        <ThemeProvider>
          {children}
        </ThemeProvider>
      </body>
    </html>
  )
}

docs.title: Segment Layouts
docs.text: You can apply a layout only to a specific subfolder. Example: app/blog/layout.js affects only blog routes.

docs.title: Route Groups with Layouts
docs.text:
Use folder names like (marketing) to group routes without affecting URL.

Structure:

app/
 ├ (marketing)/
 │    ├ layout.js
 │    └ page.js
 └ (dashboard)/
      ├ layout.js
      └ page.js

URL stays clean, but UI stays grouped.

docs.title: File Hierarchy Summary
docs.text: File Purpose layout.js Shared persistent wrapper page.js Actual route content template.js Re-rendering UI wrapper loading.js Suspense loading state error.js Error boundary not-found.js 404 for that segment

docs.title: next/navigation Module in Next.js
docs.text: The next/navigation module gives you client side and server side navigation APIs in the App Router. These are the modern replacements for next/router.

docs.title: redirect(url)
docs.text:
Tells the server to immediately redirect to another route.

import { redirect } from "next/navigation";

export async function GET() {
  redirect("/login");
}

It stops execution right there and sends a redirect response.

docs.title: notFound()
docs.text:
Shows the 404 page.

import { notFound } from "next/navigation";

export async function GET() {
  const data = await fetchData();
  if (!data) notFound();
}

docs.title: useRouter()
docs.text:
Lets you navigate programmatically inside client components.

"use client";

import { useRouter } from "next/navigation";

export default function Page() {
  const router = useRouter();

  function go() {
    router.push("/dashboard");
  }

  return <button onClick={go}>Go</button>;
}

Methods available:

  • push(url)
  • replace(url)
  • back()
  • forward()
  • refresh()

docs.title: usePathname()
docs.text:
Returns the current URL path.

"use client";

import { usePathname } from "next/navigation";

export default function Example() {
  const pathname = usePathname();
  return <p>{pathname}</p>;
}

docs.title: useSearchParams()
docs.text:
Gives read-only access to query params.

"use client";

import { useSearchParams } from "next/navigation";

export default function Example() {
  const params = useSearchParams();
  const q = params.get("q");
  return <p>{q}</p>;
}

docs.title: useParams()
docs.text:
Returns dynamic route parameters.

"use client";

import { useParams } from "next/navigation";

export default function Page() {
  const params = useParams();
  // Example: { id: "123" }
  return <div>ID: {params.id}</div>;
}

docs.title: useSelectedLayoutSegments() and useSelectedLayoutSegment()
docs.text:
Used inside layouts to detect which segment of the route is active.

"use client";

import { useSelectedLayoutSegments } from "next/navigation";

export default function Nav() {
  const segments = useSelectedLayoutSegments();
  return <p>{JSON.stringify(segments)}</p>;
}

Useful for active nav link highlighting in layouts.

docs.title: SSR, SSG and ISR in Next.js
Server Side Rendering (SSR)
docs.text: SSR renders the page on the server for every request. The HTML is generated fresh each time someone visits the page.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Create an async function called getServerSideProps inside a page.

export async function getServerSideProps() {
  const data = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data").then((r) =>
    r.json()
  );

  return {
    props: { data },
  };
}

docs.title: When to use
docs.text:
• Data changes on every request
  • User-specific data
  • SEO critical pages requiring always fresh content

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• Always up-to-date
  • Great for SEO
  • Secure, since secrets stay on server

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• Slower than SSG
  • High server load

docs.title: Static Site Generation (SSG)
docs.text: SSG generates the HTML at build time. Once built, the HTML is reused for every request.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Use getStaticProps.

export async function getStaticProps() {
  const posts = await fetch("https://api.example.com/posts").then((r) =>
    r.json()
  );

  return {
    props: { posts },
  };
}

docs.title: When to use
docs.text:
• Content does not change often
  • Blog posts, docs, product listings
  • Maximum performance

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• Fastest performance
  • Zero server load
  • Great for SEO

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• Requires rebuild to update data
  • Not suitable for rapidly changing content

docs.title: Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR)
docs.text:
What it is ISR updates static pages after deployment without rebuilding the entire app. Next.js regenerates the page in the background after a set time.

How to use Add a revalidate key in getStaticProps.

export async function getStaticProps() {
  const data = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data").then((r) =>
    r.json()
  );

  return {
    props: { data },
    revalidate: 60, // regenerate every 60 seconds
  };
}

docs.title: When to use
docs.text:
• Content updates regularly but not per-request
  • News, listings, dashboards, blogs with frequent updates

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• Best of SSG and SSR
  • Low server load
  • Automatically keeps pages fresh

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• Updates are not instant
  • User may see slightly old content within revalidate window

docs.title: Why Environment Variables Matter
docs.text: Environment variables let you store sensitive values outside your codebase. They keep secrets secure and allow different values for development and production.

docs.title: Public Variables
docs.text:
These start with NEXT_PUBLIC_. They are exposed to the browser.

Example:

NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL=https://example.com/api

Use in code:

const url = process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL;

docs.title: Server Only Variables
docs.text:
These do not start with NEXT_PUBLIC_. They are available only on the server.

Example:

DATABASE_URL=mongodb+srv://...

Use in server components, API routes, and server actions:

const db = process.env.DATABASE_URL;

docs.title: Where Environment Files Go
docs.text:
Next.js loads variables from these files:

  1. .env.local (git ignored, highest priority)
  2. .env.development
  3. .env.production
  4. .env

Example folder:

project/
  .env.local
  .env
  .env.production

docs.title: In Server Components
docs.text: console.log(process.env.SECRET_KEY);

docs.title: In Client Components
docs.text:
Only public variables can be accessed.

"use client";

console.log(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_KEY);

docs.title: Environment Variables in next.config.js
docs.text:
You can define custom environment variables inside config.

// next.config.js
module.exports = {
  env: {
    CUSTOM_KEY: "value",
  },
};

Access anywhere:

process.env.CUSTOM_KEY;

docs.title: Vercel
docs.text: Go to: Settings > Environment Variables > Add > Redeploy

docs.title: Other Platforms
docs.text: Each platform has its own dashboard to add variables. Never push .env.local to GitHub.

docs.title: When You Need to Restart Dev Server
docs.text:
If you change a variable in .env.local, restart the dev server:

npm run dev

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Never commit secrets to GitHub.
  • Use NEXT_PUBLIC_ only for safe-to-share values.
  • Split variables per environment using .env.development and .env.production.
  • Validate required variables on server start to avoid runtime issues.

docs.title: Example Setup
docs.text:
.env.local

DATABASE_URL=...
JWT_SECRET=...
NEXT_PUBLIC_SITE_NAME=MySite

Usage:

const db = process.env.DATABASE_URL;
const siteName = process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_SITE_NAME;

docs.title: What is Styled JSX
docs.text: Styled JSX is a built in CSS in JS solution for styling components in Next.js. It lets you write scoped CSS inside a component so the styles apply only to that component.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
export default function Button() {
  return (
    <>
      <button>Click</button>

      <style jsx>{`
        button {
          background: blue;
          color: white;
          padding: 10px 20px;
          border-radius: 6px;
        }
      `}</style>
    </>
  );
}

docs.title: Scoped Styling
docs.text: Styles apply only to elements inside the component. They never leak outside.

docs.title: Global Styling
docs.text:
If you want a style to apply globally:

<style jsx global>{`
  body {
    margin: 0;
    font-family: sans-serif;
  }
`}</style>

docs.title: Dynamic Styling (Using Props)
docs.text:
export default function Box({ color }) {
  return (
    <>
      <div className="box" />

      <style jsx>{`
        .box {
          width: 100px;
          height: 100px;
          background: ${color};
        }
      `}</style>
    </>
  );
}

docs.title: Other Ways to Style in Next.js
1. Global CSS Files
docs.text:
Used for app wide styles.

Create a file like:

app/globals.css

Import in app/layout.js:

import "./globals.css";

docs.title: 2. CSS Modules
docs.text:
CSS scoped to a specific component through filenames ending with .module.css.

Example:

Button.module.css

.btn {
  background: tomato;
  padding: 10px 20px;
}

Use in component:

import styles from "./Button.module.css";

export default function Button() {
  return <button className={styles.btn}>Click</button>;
}

docs.title: 3. Tailwind CSS
docs.text:
A utility first CSS framework. Very popular in Next.js projects.

Install normally then use classes:

<button className="bg-blue-600 text-white px-4 py-2 rounded">Click</button>

docs.title: 4. Inline Styles
docs.text:
Simple quick styling.

<div style={{ color: "red", padding: "20px" }}>Hello</div>

docs.title: 5. CSS in JS Libraries (Styled Components / Emotion)
docs.text: These give component level styling with features like theming.

docs.title: Styled Components Example:
docs.text:
import styled from "styled-components";

const Button = styled.button`
  background: purple;
  color: white;
  padding: 10px 20px;
`;

export default function App() {
  return <Button>Click</Button>;
}

docs.title: 6. Sass / SCSS Support
docs.text:
Next.js supports .scss out of the box.

Example:

styles/main.scss

Import in layout.js or any component:

import "./main.scss";

docs.title: 7. Using classnames
docs.text:
Helps conditionally apply classes with CSS Modules or global CSS.

import cn from "classnames";
import styles from "./Box.module.css";

<div className={cn(styles.box, isActive && styles.active)} />;

docs.title: What is Node.js?
docs.text: Node.js is a runtime environment that allows JavaScript to run outside the browser using Chrome's V8 engine. It's designed for building fast, scalable, and efficient network applications — especially servers and CLI tools.

docs.title: Key Features:
docs.text:
• Asynchronous and non-blocking
  • Built on event-driven architecture
  • JavaScript on the backend
  • Fast execution (compiled to machine code)
  • Access to built-in modules (fs, http, path, etc.)

docs.title: How Node.js Works
docs.text:
Node.js uses an event loop and callback queue to handle I/O asynchronously:

  1. Single-threaded main loop
  2. Background threads for I/O via libuv
  3. Uses callbacks, Promises, or async/await for async flow

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• REST APIs and backend servers
  • Real-time apps (chat, games)
  • File processing scripts
  • Command-line tools
  • Microservices architecture

docs.title: 1. Install Node.js
docs.text: Download and install from: https://nodejs.org Choose the LTS version unless you need the latest features.

docs.title: 2. Verify Installation
docs.text:
node -v    # Node.js version
npm -v     # npm (Node Package Manager) version

docs.title: Running JavaScript with Node
docs.text:
Create a file:

// hello.js
console.log("Hello from Node.js");

Run it in the terminal:

node hello.js

docs.title: Node REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop)
docs.text:
An interactive shell to execute JS line-by-line.

Start it:

node

Try this:

> 5 + 3
8
> const name = "Node"
> name.toUpperCase()
'NODE'

Exit:

Ctrl + C (twice)

docs.title: What Are Modules?
docs.text:
Modules are independent blocks of reusable code. In Node.js, every file is treated as a separate module.

There are three types of modules:

  1. Core (built-in)
  2. Custom (user-defined)
  3. Third-party (npm packages)

docs.title: Exporting in one file
docs.text:
// math.js
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}
module.exports = add;

docs.title: Importing in another
docs.text:
// app.js
const add = require("./math");
console.log(add(2, 3)); // 5

You can export multiple values:

module.exports = {
  add,
  subtract
};

docs.title: ES Modules (import/export)
docs.text:
Supported with .mjs extension or "type": "module" in package.json.

// math.mjs
export function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

// app.mjs
import { add } from './math.mjs';
console.log(add(5, 6));

docs.title: Built-in Modules
docs.text:
Node provides many core modules out of the box. Common ones:

  • fs – file system
  • path – file paths
  • http – create web servers
  • os – system info
  • events – event emitter

Example:

const path = require("path");

console.log(__filename);                  // full file path
console.log(path.basename(__filename));  // file name

docs.title: Creating Custom Modules
docs.text:
Every file is its own module. Use module.exports to export, and require() to import.

// logger.js
function log(msg) {
  console.log(`[LOG]: ${msg}`);
}
module.exports = log;

// main.js
const log = require("./logger");
log("App started");

docs.title: Intro to npm (Node Package Manager)
docs.text:
npm lets you install and manage third-party packages.

Check version:

npm -v

Initialize a project:

npm init -y

This creates a package.json file that stores metadata and dependencies.

docs.title: Installing Packages
docs.text:
Install locally:

npm install chalk

Use:

const chalk = require("chalk");
console.log(chalk.green("Success!"));

Install globally:

npm install -g nodemon

docs.title: Dev Dependencies
docs.text:
Install a package for development only:

npm install nodemon --save-dev

docs.title: package.json Basics
docs.text:
{
  "name": "project-name",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node index.js",

docs.text: Tracks exact versions of all installed packages to ensure consistency across environments.
