docs.title: File System (fs module)
docs.text:
The fs module allows you to interact with the file system (read, write, update, delete files/directories).

const fs = require("fs");

docs.title: Read a File (async)
docs.text:
fs.readFile("file.txt", "utf8", (err, data) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log(data);
});

docs.title: Read a File (sync)
docs.text:
const data = fs.readFileSync("file.txt", "utf8");
console.log(data);

docs.title: Write a File (overwrite)
docs.text:
fs.writeFile("output.txt", "Hello world", (err) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log("Written successfully");
});

docs.title: Append to a File
docs.text:
fs.appendFile("output.txt", "\nNew line", (err) => {
  if (err) throw err;
});

docs.title: Delete a File
docs.text:
fs.unlink("output.txt", (err) => {
  if (err) throw err;
});

docs.title: Create a Directory
docs.text:
fs.mkdir("myFolder", (err) => {
  if (err) throw err;
});

docs.title: Read Directory Contents
docs.text:
fs.readdir(".", (err, files) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log(files);
});

docs.title: Remove a Directory
docs.text:
fs.rmdir("myFolder", (err) => {
  if (err) throw err;
});

docs.title: fs.promises (modern promise-based API)
docs.text:
const fsPromises = require("fs").promises;

async function readFile() {
  const data = await fsPromises.readFile("file.txt", "utf8");
  console.log(data);
}

docs.title: Path Module
docs.text:
The path module is used to work with file and directory paths in a platform-independent way.

const path = require("path");

docs.title: Common Methods
docs.text:
__dirname                // current directory
__filename               // current file path

path.basename(__filename)    // just file name
path.dirname(__filename)     // directory name
path.extname(__filename)     // file extension
path.join("folder", "file.txt")  // cross-platform path
path.resolve("folder", "file.txt") // absolute path

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
const filePath = path.join(__dirname, "data", "info.txt");
console.log(filePath);

docs.title: HTTP Module
docs.text:
The http module lets you create a basic web server without using any external frameworks.

const http = require("http");

docs.title: Create a Basic Server
docs.text:
const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {
  res.write("Hello from Node.js server");
  res.end();
});

server.listen(3000, () => {
  console.log("Server running on http://localhost:3000");
});

docs.title: Handling Routes
docs.text:
Use req.url to detect the requested path and req.method to detect the HTTP method.

const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {
  if (req.url === "/") {
    res.write("Home Page");
  } else if (req.url === "/about") {
    res.write("About Page");
  } else {
    res.writeHead(404);
    res.write("Page Not Found");
  }
  res.end();
});

docs.title: Sending JSON
docs.text:
if (req.url === "/api") {
  res.writeHead(200, { "Content-Type": "application/json" });
  res.end(JSON.stringify({ name: "Node", version: "1.0" }));
}

docs.title: Serving HTML Files
docs.text:
const fs = require("fs");

if (req.url === "/home") {
  fs.readFile("index.html", (err, data) => {
    if (err) {
      res.writeHead(500);
      res.end("Server Error");
      return;
    }
    res.writeHead(200, { "Content-Type": "text/html" });
    res.end(data);
  });
}

docs.title: Handling Query Parameters
docs.text:
const url = require("url");

const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {
  const parsedUrl = url.parse(req.url, true); // true to parse query
  const name = parsedUrl.query.name;
  res.end(`Hello ${name}`);
});

Example: Request to /greet?name=John → Response: Hello John

docs.title: Setting Headers
docs.text:
res.writeHead(200, {
  "Content-Type": "text/plain",
  "Custom-Header": "value"
});

docs.title: HTTP Status Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 200 OK 404 Not Found 500 Internal Server Error

docs.title: EventEmitter (events module)
docs.text:
Node.js uses the EventEmitter pattern to handle asynchronous events. It's part of the built-in events module.

const EventEmitter = require("events");
const emitter = new EventEmitter();

docs.title: Emitting and Listening to Events
docs.text:
emitter.on("greet", (name) => {
  console.log(`Hello, ${name}`);
});

emitter.emit("greet", "Alice"); // Hello, Alice

docs.title: Multiple Listeners
docs.text:
You can register multiple listeners to the same event.

emitter.on("log", () => console.log("Listener 1"));
emitter.on("log", () => console.log("Listener 2"));
emitter.emit("log");

docs.title: Once
docs.text:
Use .once() to listen only one time.

emitter.once("data", () => console.log("Received once"));
emitter.emit("data"); // Triggers
emitter.emit("data"); // Ignored

docs.title: Remove Listener
docs.text:
function log() {
  console.log("Log event");
}

emitter.on("log", log);
emitter.removeListener("log", log);

docs.title: Streams
docs.text:
Streams handle data in chunks, great for large files or network traffic.

Four types:

  • Readable
  • Writable
  • Duplex (read + write)
  • Transform (modify during read/write)

docs.title: Readable Stream Example
docs.text:
const fs = require("fs");
const readStream = fs.createReadStream("bigfile.txt", "utf8");

readStream.on("data", (chunk) => {
  console.log("Received chunk:", chunk);
});

docs.title: Writable Stream Example
docs.text:
const writeStream = fs.createWriteStream("output.txt");

writeStream.write("Line 1\n");
writeStream.write("Line 2\n");
writeStream.end();

docs.title: Pipe
docs.text:
Use .pipe() to connect readable to writable stream.

const fs = require("fs");

const input = fs.createReadStream("source.txt");
const output = fs.createWriteStream("copy.txt");

input.pipe(output);

docs.title: Buffer
docs.text:
Buffers are raw binary data stored in memory outside the V8 heap.

const buf = Buffer.from("Hello");
console.log(buf);           // <Buffer 48 65 6c 6c 6f>
console.log(buf.toString()); // Hello

Use Buffers when working with streams, sockets, or binary files.

docs.title: The process Object
docs.text: process is a global object in Node.js that provides information and control over the current Node.js process.

docs.title: Access Command Line Arguments
docs.text:
console.log(process.argv);

Run:

node app.js hello world

Result:

[
  '/path/to/node',
  '/path/to/app.js',
  'hello',
  'world'
]

Use process.argv.slice(2) to ignore the first two entries.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
console.log(process.env.NODE_ENV);

Set:

NODE_ENV=development node app.js

Use .env files in real apps (with dotenv package).

docs.title: Exit Code
docs.text:
process.exit(0); // success
process.exit(1); // failure

docs.title: Events
docs.text:
process.on("exit", (code) => {
  console.log("Exiting with code:", code);
});

docs.title: Global Variables
docs.text: These are available in every Node.js file.

docs.title: __dirname
docs.text:
Absolute path of the current directory.

console.log(__dirname);

docs.title: __filename
docs.text:
Absolute path of the current file.

console.log(__filename);

docs.title: require
docs.text:
Used to import CommonJS modules.

const fs = require("fs");

docs.title: module and exports
docs.text:
Control what a module exposes.

module.exports = {}; // or exports.myFunc = ...

docs.title: setTimeout and setInterval
docs.text:
Work like in the browser but run in Node’s event loop.

setTimeout(() => {
  console.log("After 1 second");
}, 1000);

const intervalId = setInterval(() => {
  console.log("Repeating");
}, 2000);

setTimeout(() => clearInterval(intervalId), 7000); // stop after 7s

docs.title: Reading from stdin
docs.text:
process.stdin.on("data", (data) => {
  console.log(`You typed: ${data.toString().trim()}`);
});

To use:

node app.js
# then type something and press Enter

docs.title: Handling Errors with try/catch
docs.text:
Use try/catch to handle synchronous errors.

try {
  const result = riskyFunction();
  console.log(result);
} catch (err) {
  console.error("Error:", err.message);
}

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
try {
  const x = y + 1; // y is not defined
} catch (err) {
  console.error("Caught error:", err.message);
}

docs.title: Handling Async Errors with Promises
docs.text:
fetchData()
  .then((res) => {
    console.log(res);
  })
  .catch((err) => {
    console.error("Error:", err);
  });

docs.title: Async/Await with try/catch
docs.text:
async function loadData() {
  try {
    const res = await fetchSomething();
    console.log(res);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("Async Error:", err.message);
  }
}

docs.title: Emitting and Handling Error Events
docs.text:
Some core modules like streams emit error events.

const fs = require("fs");
const stream = fs.createReadStream("missing.txt");

stream.on("error", (err) => {
  console.error("Stream error:", err.message);
});

docs.title: Throwing Custom Errors
docs.text:
function divide(a, b) {
  if (b === 0) throw new Error("Cannot divide by zero");
  return a / b;
}

docs.title: Global Error Handlers
docs.text:
Catch unhandled errors:

process.on("uncaughtException", (err) => {
  console.error("Uncaught Exception:", err);
});

For unhandled Promise rejections:

process.on("unhandledRejection", (reason) => {
  console.error("Unhandled Rejection:", reason);
});

docs.title: 1. console.log
docs.text:
Simple and fast, use it to inspect values.

console.log("Debug here:", variable);

docs.title: 2. debugger Keyword
docs.text:
Pauses execution like a breakpoint.

function test() {
  const a = 5;
  debugger;
  const b = a + 10;
  return b;
}

Run with:

node inspect app.js

Then use n, c, repl, etc. to step through the code.

docs.title: 3. VS Code Debugger
docs.text:
• Set breakpoints directly in the editor
  • Use launch configuration (.vscode/launch.json)
  • Run using the built-in debugger

docs.title: Working with JSON
docs.text: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is commonly used for configuration, data files, and APIs.

docs.title: Read JSON from a File
docs.text:
const fs = require("fs");

const data = fs.readFileSync("data.json", "utf8");
const parsed = JSON.parse(data);

console.log(parsed.name);

docs.title: Write JSON to a File
docs.text:
const user = { name: "Alice", age: 25 };
const json = JSON.stringify(user, null, 2); // pretty print

fs.writeFileSync("user.json", json);

docs.title: Parse and Stringify
docs.text:
const obj = JSON.parse('{"name": "Bob"}');
const str = JSON.stringify(obj);

docs.title: Timers
docs.text: Node provides timer functions similar to the browser.

docs.title: setTimeout
docs.text:
Run a function once after a delay (ms).

setTimeout(() => {
  console.log("Delayed message");
}, 1000);

docs.title: setInterval
docs.text:
Run a function repeatedly at an interval (ms).

const intervalId = setInterval(() => {
  console.log("Repeats every 2s");
}, 2000);

setTimeout(() => clearInterval(intervalId), 7000); // stop after 7s

docs.title: setImmediate
docs.text:
Runs a callback after the current event loop phase.

setImmediate(() => {
  console.log("Runs immediately after current task");
});

docs.title: clearTimeout / clearInterval
docs.text:
Stop scheduled timers.

const id = setTimeout(() => {}, 5000);
clearTimeout(id);

docs.title: Reading Command-Line Arguments
docs.text:
const args = process.argv.slice(2);
console.log(args); // ["hello", "world"]

Run with:

node script.js hello world

docs.title: Simple Flag Parser
docs.text:
const flags = {};
process.argv.slice(2).forEach(arg => {
  const [key, value] = arg.split("=");
  flags[key] = value;
});

console.log(flags);
// node app.js name=alice age=30
// Output: { name: 'alice', age: '30' }

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Meta (formerly Facebook) and used in production by companies like Instagram, Netflix, and Airbnb.

docs.title: What is React?
docs.text:
• A component-based, declarative library for building UI.
  • Focuses only on the View in MVC (Model-View-Controller).
  • Uses a virtual DOM for fast rendering.
  • Enables reactive, state-driven UI development.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text: Feature Description Component-Based Breaks UI into reusable pieces (components). Declarative Describe what UI should look like based on state. Virtual DOM Efficiently updates only what's changed. JSX JavaScript + XML syntax for describing UI. Unidirectional Data Flow Data flows from parent to child only.

docs.title: Why Use React?
docs.text:
• Faster DOM updates via virtual DOM
  • Organized and reusable component structure
  • Strong ecosystem (React Router, Redux, Hooks, etc.)
  • Large community and long-term support
  • Works with any backend or other libraries

docs.title: JSX: JavaScript + XML
docs.text:
JSX lets you write HTML-like code inside JavaScript.

const element = <h1>Hello, React!</h1>;

This is converted to:

React.createElement("h1", null, "Hello, React!");

docs.title: Basic Component Example
docs.text:
function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

export default Welcome;

Usage:

<Welcome name="Alice" />

docs.title: State and Props
docs.text:
• Props: Read-only data passed to a component
  • State: Mutable data local to a component
import { useState } from "react";

function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
  return (
    <div>
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Increment</button>
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: React Project Structure (Vite)
docs.text:
npm create vite@latest my-app --template react
cd my-app
npm install
npm run dev

Main files:

my-app/
├─ src/
│  ├─ App.jsx
│  ├─ main.jsx
├─ index.html
├─ package.json

docs.title: Common React Tools & Libraries
docs.text:
• Vite / Create React App – setup tools
  • React Router – routing
  • Redux / Context API – state management
  • React Query / SWR – data fetching and caching
  • Tailwind / Styled Components – styling

docs.title: Components and Props
docs.text: In React, components are the core building blocks of the UI. They allow you to split the interface into independent, reusable pieces.

docs.title: 1. What is a Component?
docs.text: A component is a JavaScript function (or class) that returns a React element (JSX).

docs.title: Functional Component Example:
docs.text:
function Greeting() {
  return <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;
}

You use it like an HTML tag:

<Greeting />

docs.title: 2. Types of Components
docs.text:
Type Description Functional Basic functions that return JSX Class-based (legacy) Older style with class extends React.Component

Modern React uses functional components with Hooks.

docs.title: 3. Component Naming Rules
docs.text:
• Must start with an uppercase letter (<MyComponent />)
  • Must return one root element (wrap multiple with a <div> or fragment)

docs.title: 4. Props (Properties)
docs.text: Props are inputs passed into components, similar to arguments in a function.

docs.title: Passing Props:
docs.text:
function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

// Usage:
<Welcome name="Alice" />

Using destructuring:

function Welcome({ name }) {
  return <h1>Hello, {name}</h1>;
}

docs.title: 5. Multiple Props Example
docs.text:
function Profile({ name, age }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <p>Name: {name}</p>
      <p>Age: {age}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

// Usage:
<Profile name="Bob" age={20} />

docs.title: 6. Default Props
docs.text:
You can define fallback values if a prop is not passed.

function Button({ label = "Click Me" }) {
  return <button>{label}</button>;
}

Or explicitly:

Button.defaultProps = {
  label: "Click Me"
};

docs.title: 7. Props Are Read-Only
docs.text:
Props cannot be modified inside the component. They are passed from parent to child and are immutable.

function ChangeName({ name }) {
  name = "New Name"; // ❌ Don't do this
}

docs.title: 8. Children Prop
docs.text:
props.children allows you to pass elements between component tags.

function Card({ children }) {
  return <div className="card">{children}</div>;
}

<Card>
  <h2>Title</h2>
  <p>Description inside the card.</p>
</Card>

docs.title: 9. Conditional Rendering with Props
docs.text:
function Status({ isOnline }) {
  return <p>{isOnline ? "Online" : "Offline"}</p>;
}

docs.title: Hooks and State
docs.text: Hooks are functions that let you use React features like state and lifecycle in functional components.

docs.title: 1. What is State?
docs.text: State is data that changes over time and affects what gets rendered on the screen.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
  return (
    <div>
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>+</button>
    </div>
  );
}
  • useState(0) initializes count to 0
  • setCount() updates it and re-renders the component

docs.title: 2. useState Hook
docs.text:
const [state, setState] = useState(initialValue);
  • Can hold numbers, strings, objects, arrays, etc.
  • Updating state causes a re-render
  • Don't mutate state directly

docs.title: Example with Object:
docs.text:
const [user, setUser] = useState({ name: "Rahul", age: 15 });

setUser({ ...user, age: 16 }); // use spread to keep other properties

docs.title: 3. Rules of Hooks
docs.text:
1. Only call hooks at the top level (not inside loops, conditions, or nested functions)
  2. Only call hooks inside React components or custom hooks

docs.title: 4. Multiple useState Hooks
docs.text:
You can use multiple useState calls in one component:

const [name, setName] = useState("");
const [email, setEmail] = useState("");

docs.title: 5. useEffect Hook (Intro)
docs.text:
useEffect runs code after render. Commonly used for:

  • Fetching data
  • Subscribing/unsubscribing
  • DOM updates
useEffect(() => {
  console.log("Component mounted or state changed");
}, [dependency]);
  • Runs on mount and whenever dependencies change
  • Empty dependency array [] = run once on mount

docs.title: 6. Derived State from Props
docs.text:
Avoid copying props into state unless necessary. Instead, compute directly in JSX:

function Greeting({ name }) {
  return <h1>Hello, {name.toUpperCase()}</h1>;
}

docs.title: 7. Updating State Based on Previous Value
docs.text:
Always use a function when new state depends on old state:

setCount(prev => prev + 1);

docs.title: 8. useState with Arrays
docs.text:
const [items, setItems] = useState([]);

setItems([...items, newItem]); // add item
setItems(items.filter(item => item.id !== id)); // remove item

docs.title: 9. Controlled Components
docs.text:
Inputs should be controlled by React state:

const [text, setText] = useState("");

<input value={text} onChange={(e) => setText(e.target.value)} />

docs.title: useEffect Hook
docs.text: The useEffect hook lets you perform side effects in functional components — like fetching data, setting up subscriptions, timers, or manually changing the DOM.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  // code to run after render
}, [dependencies]);
  • Runs after every render by default
  • The second argument (dependency array) controls when it runs

docs.title: 2. No Dependency Array
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  console.log("Runs after every render");
});
  • Executes after every re-render

docs.title: 3. Empty Dependency Array []
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  console.log("Runs once on mount");
}, []);
  • Runs only once when the component is mounted (like componentDidMount)

docs.title: 4. With Dependencies
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  console.log("Runs when count changes");
}, [count]);
  • Runs when count changes
  • Add all external state/props used in the effect to the array

docs.title: 5. Cleanup Function
docs.text:
Return a function inside useEffect to handle cleanup (e.g., remove event listeners, clear intervals):

useEffect(() => {
  const id = setInterval(() => {
    console.log("tick");
  }, 1000);

  return () => {
    clearInterval(id); // cleanup on unmount or re-run
  };
}, []);

docs.title: 6. Fetching Data Example
docs.text:
import { useState, useEffect } from "react";

function Users() {
  const [users, setUsers] = useState([]);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch("https://api.example.com/users")
      .then(res => res.json())
      .then(data => setUsers(data));
  }, []);

  return (
    <ul>
      {users.map(user => <li key={user.id}>{user.name}</li>)}
    </ul>
  );
}

docs.title: 7. Multiple Effects
docs.text:
You can use useEffect multiple times per component for separation of concerns.

useEffect(() => {
  // first effect
}, [a]);

useEffect(() => {
  // second effect
}, [b]);

docs.title: 8. Infinite Loop Warning
docs.text:
Don’t update state directly inside useEffect without a condition or it will cause an infinite render loop.

useEffect(() => {
  setCount(count + 1); // BAD: triggers render → runs again
});

docs.title: useRef Hook
docs.text: The useRef hook gives you a mutable reference to a DOM element or any value that persists across renders without causing re-renders.

docs.title: 1. Syntax
docs.text:
const ref = useRef(initialValue);
  • ref.current holds the value
  • Unlike state, updating ref.current doesn’t re-render the component

docs.title: 2. Accessing DOM Elements
docs.text:
import { useRef, useEffect } from "react";

function InputFocus() {
  const inputRef = useRef(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    inputRef.current.focus(); // focus input on mount
  }, []);

  return <input ref={inputRef} type="text" />;
}
  • The ref is attached to the JSX element
  • After mounting, ref.current points to the DOM node

docs.title: 3. Persisting Values Without Re-Renders
docs.text:
function Timer() {
  const count = useRef(0);

  useEffect(() => {
    const interval = setInterval(() => {
      count.current += 1;
      console.log(count.current);
    }, 1000);
    return () => clearInterval(interval);
  }, []);
}
  • count is preserved between renders
  • Changes to count.current do not trigger a re-render

docs.title: 4. useRef vs useState
docs.text: Feature useRef useState Causes re-render ❌ No ✅ Yes Stores value ✅ Yes ✅ Yes DOM access ✅ Yes (ref.current) ❌ No Use case DOM refs, timers, persistent vars UI state / reactive data

docs.title: 5. useRef in Event Handlers
docs.text:
Good for holding previous values or timers:

const intervalRef = useRef(null);

function stopTimer() {
  clearInterval(intervalRef.current);
}

docs.title: 6. Forwarding Refs (Advanced)
docs.text:
To pass a ref to a child component:

const Input = React.forwardRef((props, ref) => {
  return <input ref={ref} {...props} />;
});

docs.title: Conditional Rendering and Rendering Lists
docs.text: React lets you render components or elements dynamically based on conditions or data arrays. This is done using JavaScript logic inside JSX.

docs.title: 1. Conditional Rendering
docs.text: You can conditionally show UI using if, ternary, &&, or conditional functions.

docs.title: a. Using if-else (outside JSX)
docs.text:
function Message({ isLoggedIn }) {
  if (isLoggedIn) {
    return <h1>Welcome back!</h1>;
  } else {
    return <h1>Please sign in.</h1>;
  }
}

docs.title: b. Ternary Operator
docs.text: <p>{isDarkMode ? "Dark Mode" : "Light Mode"}</p>

docs.title: c. Logical AND (&&)
docs.text:
{isAdmin && <button>Delete</button>}

Only renders <button> if isAdmin is true.

docs.title: 2. Prevent Rendering
docs.text:
Return null to render nothing:

if (!user) return null;

docs.title: 3. Rendering Lists
docs.text:
Use Array.map() to render elements from data:

const users = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"];

<ul>
  {users.map((name, index) => (
    <li key={index}>{name}</li>
  ))}
</ul>
  • Wrap with a container (<ul> or <div>)
  • Use a unique key prop for each item

docs.title: 4. Rendering List of Objects
docs.text:
const todos = [
  { id: 1, task: "Read" },
  { id: 2, task: "Write" }
];

<ul>
  {todos.map(todo => (
    <li key={todo.id}>{todo.task}</li>
  ))}
</ul>

docs.title: 5. Conditional Rendering Inside Map
docs.text:
{todos.map(todo => (
  <li key={todo.id}>
    {todo.completed ? <s>{todo.task}</s> : todo.task}
  </li>
))}

docs.title: 6. Key Prop (Important)
docs.text:
• Must be unique and stable
  • Never use index as key if list can change
  • Keys help React track what changed efficiently

docs.title: Handling Events
docs.text: React events are similar to DOM events but use camelCase and work consistently across browsers. Event handlers are written as functions and passed as props.

docs.title: 1. Adding Event Handlers
docs.text:
function Button() {
  function handleClick() {
    alert("Button clicked!");
  }

  return <button onClick={handleClick}>Click Me</button>;
}
  • Use onClick, onChange, onSubmit, etc.
  • Must be camelCase (onClick not onclick)

docs.title: 2. Inline Event Handler
docs.text:
<button onClick={() => alert("Clicked!")}>Click Me</button>

Good for simple cases, but avoid complex logic inside JSX.

docs.title: 3. Passing Arguments to Event Handlers
docs.text:
function Greeting({ name }) {
  function sayHello(user) {
    alert("Hello, " + user);
  }

  return <button onClick={() => sayHello(name)}>Greet</button>;
}

docs.title: 4. Event Object
docs.text:
React passes a synthetic event object automatically.

function Input() {
  function handleChange(event) {
    console.log(event.target.value);
  }

  return <input type="text" onChange={handleChange} />;
}
  • event.target.value gives input value
  • Works similar to native DOM event

docs.title: 5. Common Events
docs.text: Event Usage Example onClick <button onClick={fn} /> onChange <input onChange={fn} /> onSubmit <form onSubmit={fn} /> onMouseEnter <div onMouseEnter={fn} /> onKeyDown <input onKeyDown={fn} />

docs.title: 6. Prevent Default Behavior
docs.text:
function Form() {
  function handleSubmit(e) {
    e.preventDefault(); // stops page reload
    console.log("Form submitted!");
  }

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
      <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
  );
}

docs.title: 7. Event Binding in Loops
docs.text:
const items = ["A", "B", "C"];

<ul>
  {items.map((item, i) => (
    <li key={i} onClick={() => console.log(item)}>{item}</li>
  ))}
</ul>

docs.title: 8. Synthetic Events
docs.text:
React uses SyntheticEvent, a wrapper for native events:

  • Provides cross-browser compatibility
  • Behaves like the native event object

docs.title: React Router
docs.text: React Router is a library used for handling navigation and routing in React applications. It allows you to create single-page applications (SPAs) with multiple views.

docs.title: 1. Installation
docs.text: npm install react-router-dom

docs.title: 2. Basic Setup
docs.text:
Wrap your app with BrowserRouter in the root file:

import { BrowserRouter } from "react-router-dom";
import App from "./App";

root.render(
  <BrowserRouter>
    <App />
  </BrowserRouter>
);

docs.title: 3. Defining Routes
docs.text:
import { Routes, Route } from "react-router-dom";
import Home from "./Home";
import About from "./About";

function App() {
  return (
    <Routes>
      <Route path="/" element={<Home />} />
      <Route path="/about" element={<About />} />
    </Routes>
  );
}
  • path = URL
  • element = Component to render

docs.title: 4. Link Component
docs.text:
Use Link instead of <a> for navigation (prevents page reload).

import { Link } from "react-router-dom";

<Link to="/">Home</Link>
<Link to="/about">About</Link>

docs.title: 5. useNavigate Hook
docs.text:
Programmatic navigation:

import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom";

function Dashboard() {
  const navigate = useNavigate();

  return <button onClick={() => navigate("/login")}>Go to Login</button>;
}

docs.title: 6. useParams Hook
docs.text:
Get URL parameters:

<Route path="/user/:id" element={<User />} />;

function User() {
  const { id } = useParams();
  return <h1>User ID: {id}</h1>;
}

Visiting /user/42 renders "User ID: 42".

docs.title: 7. useSearchParams Hook
docs.text:
Get query string values:

import { useSearchParams } from "react-router-dom";

function Products() {
  const [searchParams] = useSearchParams();
  const category = searchParams.get("category");

  return <p>Category: {category}</p>;
}

URL: /products?category=books

docs.title: 8. Nested Routes
docs.text:
<Routes>
  <Route path="/dashboard" element={<Dashboard />}>
    <Route path="stats" element={<Stats />} />
    <Route path="settings" element={<Settings />} />
  </Route>
</Routes>

Render child route with <Outlet /> in Dashboard.

import { Outlet } from "react-router-dom";

function Dashboard() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Dashboard</h1>
      <Outlet />
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: 9. Not Found Route
docs.text: <Route path="*" element={<h1>404 Not Found</h1>} />

docs.title: 10. Protected Routes
docs.text:
function PrivateRoute({ children }) {
  const isLoggedIn = false; // example
  return isLoggedIn ? children : <Navigate to="/login" />;
}

<Route
  path="/profile"
  element={
    <PrivateRoute>
      <Profile />
    </PrivateRoute>
  }
/>;

docs.title: useContext Hook
docs.text: The useContext hook provides a way to share state and values across the component tree without passing props manually at every level.

docs.title: 1. Creating a Context
docs.text:
import { createContext } from "react";

const ThemeContext = createContext("light"); // default value
export default ThemeContext;

docs.title: 2. Providing Context
docs.text:
Wrap components with the Provider to pass data down.

import ThemeContext from "./ThemeContext";

function App() {
  return (
    <ThemeContext.Provider value="dark">
      <Toolbar />
    </ThemeContext.Provider>
  );
}

docs.title: 3. Consuming Context with useContext
docs.text:
import { useContext } from "react";
import ThemeContext from "./ThemeContext";

function Button() {
  const theme = useContext(ThemeContext);
  return <button className={theme}>Click Me</button>;
}
  • No need for props
  • Any component inside the Provider can access the value

docs.title: 4. Nested Providers
docs.text:
You can use multiple contexts:

<UserContext.Provider value={{ name: "Alice" }}>
  <ThemeContext.Provider value="dark">
    <Dashboard />
  </ThemeContext.Provider>
</UserContext.Provider>

Each component can consume one or both contexts.

docs.title: 5. Updating Context
docs.text:
Pass state as a value:

function App() {
  const [theme, setTheme] = useState("light");

  return (
    <ThemeContext.Provider value={{ theme, setTheme }}>
      <Toolbar />
    </ThemeContext.Provider>
  );
}

Consume and update:

function ThemeToggle() {
  const { theme, setTheme } = useContext(ThemeContext);

  return (
    <button onClick={() => setTheme(theme === "light" ? "dark" : "light")}>
      Switch Theme
    </button>
  );
}

docs.title: 6. When to Use useContext
docs.text:
• Global theme (dark/light)
  • User authentication data
  • Current language/locale
  • Global settings or configurations

Avoid overusing context for everything — prefer props for local state.

docs.title: useMemo Hook
docs.text: The useMemo hook is used to memoize expensive calculations so they are not re-executed on every render unless their dependencies change.

docs.title: 1. Syntax
docs.text:
const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => computeValue(a, b), [a, b]);
  • First argument → function that returns a value
  • Second argument → dependency array
  • Recomputes only when dependencies change

docs.title: 2. Example: Expensive Calculation
docs.text:
import { useMemo, useState } from "react";

function Factorial() {
  const [num, setNum] = useState(5);
  const [theme, setTheme] = useState("light");

  const factorial = useMemo(() => {
    function calcFactorial(n) {
      console.log("Calculating...");
      return n <= 0 ? 1 : n * calcFactorial(n - 1);
    }
    return calcFactorial(num);
  }, [num]);

  return (
    <div className={theme}>
      <p>Factorial of {num} is {factorial}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setNum(num + 1)}>Increase</button>
      <button onClick={() => setTheme(theme === "light" ? "dark" : "light")}>Toggle Theme</button>
    </div>
  );
}
  • Changing theme won’t trigger recalculation of factorial
  • Calculation only runs when num changes

docs.title: 3. Without useMemo (Problem)
docs.text:
const factorial = calcFactorial(num); // recalculated every render

Even if only unrelated state changes, the function runs again → performance issue.

docs.title: 4. Memoizing Derived Data
docs.text:
const sortedItems = useMemo(() => {
  return items.sort((a, b) => a.localeCompare(b));
}, [items]);

Prevents unnecessary sorting when items hasn’t changed.

docs.title: 5. useMemo vs useCallback
docs.text:
• useMemo → memoizes a value
  • useCallback → memoizes a function

Example:

const value = useMemo(() => expensiveCalc(a), [a]);
const callback = useCallback(() => doSomething(a), [a]);

docs.title: 6. When to Use
docs.text:
• Expensive calculations (sorting, filtering, large loops)
  • Preventing unnecessary re-renders of child components
  • Memoizing derived state

Avoid using it everywhere — use only when performance issues appear.

docs.title: useCallback Hook
docs.text: The useCallback hook returns a memoized version of a callback function that only changes when its dependencies change. It is mainly used to prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components that receive functions as props.

docs.title: 1. Syntax
docs.text:
const memoizedCallback = useCallback(() => {
  // function body
}, [dependencies]);
  • First argument → function to memoize
  • Second argument → dependency array
  • Returns the same function reference unless dependencies change

docs.title: 2. Example Without useCallback (Problem)
docs.text:
function Parent() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  const increment = () => setCount(c => c + 1);

  return <Child onIncrement={increment} />;
}

function Child({ onIncrement }) {
  console.log("Child rendered");
  return <button onClick={onIncrement}>+</button>;
}

Even if unrelated state changes, increment is recreated, causing Child to re-render.

docs.title: 3. Fix with useCallback
docs.text:
function Parent() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  const increment = useCallback(() => {
    setCount(c => c + 1);
  }, []);

  return <Child onIncrement={increment} />;
}

Now, increment keeps the same reference across renders → Child won’t re-render unnecessarily.

docs.title: 4. useCallback with Dependencies
docs.text:
const handleSearch = useCallback(() => {
  console.log("Searching:", query);
}, [query]);
  • The function changes only when query changes
  • Prevents re-creating function on unrelated updates

docs.title: 5. useCallback with React.memo
docs.text:
Often combined with React.memo for optimization:

const Child = React.memo(function Child({ onClick }) {
  console.log("Child rendered");
  return <button onClick={onClick}>Click</button>;
});
  • React.memo prevents re-render if props don’t change
  • useCallback ensures the function prop doesn’t change unnecessarily

docs.title: 6. useCallback vs useMemo
7. When to Use
docs.text:
• When passing functions as props to memoized child components
  • Preventing re-renders caused by changing function references
  • Optimizing lists with callbacks (e.g., onClick, onChange)

Avoid overusing — only apply when child components re-render unnecessarily.

docs.title: Hook Form
docs.text: React Hook Form is a library that makes handling forms in React simpler and more efficient. It minimizes re-renders, provides built-in validation, and works with both controlled and uncontrolled inputs.

docs.title: 1. Installation
docs.text: npm install react-hook-form

docs.title: 2. Basic Usage
docs.text:
import { useForm } from "react-hook-form";

function App() {
  const { register, handleSubmit } = useForm();

  const onSubmit = (data) => {
    console.log(data);
  };

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit(onSubmit)}>
      <input {...register("username")} />
      <input type="password" {...register("password")} />
      <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
  );
}
  • register("fieldName") connects input to the form
  • handleSubmit(onSubmit) handles form submission
  • data contains form values

docs.title: 3. Validation
docs.text:
Add validation rules directly in register.

<input
  {...register("email", { required: true, pattern: /^\S+@\S+$/i })}
/>

Show error messages:

const { register, handleSubmit, formState: { errors } } = useForm();

{errors.email && <p>Email is required and must be valid</p>}

docs.title: 4. Default Values
docs.text:
const { register } = useForm({
  defaultValues: {
    username: "guest",
    age: 18
  }
});

docs.title: 5. Handling Different Inputs
docs.text:
<select {...register("gender")}>
  <option value="male">Male</option>
  <option value="female">Female</option>
</select>

<input type="checkbox" {...register("subscribe")} />

docs.title: 6. Watching Values
docs.text:
const { register, watch } = useForm();
const username = watch("username");

<p>Username: {username}</p>

docs.title: 7. Reset and Set Values
docs.text:
const { register, handleSubmit, reset, setValue } = useForm();

reset({ username: "", password: "" }); // reset form

setValue("username", "JohnDoe"); // set field value manually

docs.title: 8. Form Submission with Async Code
docs.text:
const onSubmit = async (data) => {
  const res = await fetch("/api", {
    method: "POST",
    body: JSON.stringify(data)
  });
  console.log(await res.json());
};

docs.title: 9. Benefits of React Hook Form
docs.text:
• Minimal re-renders (performance-friendly)
  • Simple validation
  • Easy integration with UI frameworks
  • Works with both controlled & uncontrolled components
  • Built-in error handling and helpers

docs.title: What is Redux?
docs.text: Redux is a state management library for JavaScript applications, often used with React but can also be used with Angular, Vue, or plain JS. It helps manage the state of an application in a predictable way using a single source of truth (the store).

docs.title: Why Use Redux?
docs.text:
• Centralized State Management: All application state is stored in one place (the store).
  • Predictable State Changes: State can only be changed through specific functions (reducers) triggered by actions.
  • Easier Debugging: Redux provides tools to track every state change (Redux DevTools).
  • Consistency Across Components: Different components can easily access and update the same state.
  • Improved Maintainability: Clear flow of data and separation of concerns.

docs.title: 1. Store
docs.text:
• The store is a JavaScript object that holds the entire state tree of your application.
  • There is only one store in a Redux application.
import { createStore } from "redux";
const store = createStore(reducer);

docs.title: 2. Actions
docs.text:
• Actions are plain JavaScript objects that describe what happened.
  • Each action has a type (a string constant) and optionally some payload (data).
const incrementAction = {
  type: "INCREMENT",
};

const addTodoAction = {
  type: "ADD_TODO",
  payload: "Learn Redux",
};

docs.title: 3. Reducers
docs.text:
• Reducers are pure functions that specify how the state changes in response to actions.
  • They take the current state and an action as arguments and return a new state.
function counterReducer(state = { count: 0 }, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case "INCREMENT":
      return { count: state.count + 1 };
    case "DECREMENT":
      return { count: state.count - 1 };
    default:
      return state;
  }
}

docs.title: 4. Dispatch
docs.text:
• The dispatch() function sends an action to the Redux store.
  • When an action is dispatched, the store runs the reducer to update the state.
store.dispatch({ type: "INCREMENT" });

docs.title: 5. Subscribe
docs.text:
• The subscribe() method allows you to listen for state changes in the store.
store.subscribe(() => {
  console.log(store.getState());
});

docs.title: Redux Data Flow (Unidirectional)
docs.text:
1. Dispatch an Action – Trigger an event that describes what happened.
  2. Reducer – Receives the action and current state, returns a new state.
  3. Store – Updates the state based on the reducer’s output.
  4. UI – Re-renders based on the updated state.

Flow Diagram:

UI → Action → Reducer → Store → UI

docs.title: Example: Simple Counter
docs.text:
import { createStore } from "redux";

// Reducer
function counterReducer(state = { count: 0 }, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case "INCREMENT":
      return { count: state.count + 1 };
    case "DECREMENT":
      return { count: state.count - 1 };
    default:
      return state;
  }
}

// Create store
const store = createStore(counterReducer);

// Subscribe
store.subscribe(() => console.log(store.getState()));

// Dispatch actions
store.dispatch({ type: "INCREMENT" }); // {count: 1}
store.dispatch({ type: "INCREMENT" }); // {count: 2}
store.dispatch({ type: "DECREMENT" }); // {count: 1}

docs.title: Install:
docs.text: npm install redux react-redux

docs.title: Provider Setup
docs.text:
Wrap your app with the Redux Provider to give components access to the store.

import React from "react";
import ReactDOM from "react-dom";
import { Provider } from "react-redux";
import { createStore } from "redux";
import App from "./App";
import counterReducer from "./counterReducer";

const store = createStore(counterReducer);

ReactDOM.render(
  <Provider store={store}>
    <App />
  </Provider>,
  document.getElementById("root")
);

docs.title: Accessing State and Dispatch in Components
useDispatch – to send actions
docs.text:
import React from "react";
import { useSelector, useDispatch } from "react-redux";

function Counter() {
  const count = useSelector((state) => state.count);
  const dispatch = useDispatch();

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{count}</h1>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: "INCREMENT" })}>+</button>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: "DECREMENT" })}>-</button>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Counter;

docs.title: Redux Toolkit (RTK)
docs.text: Redux Toolkit simplifies Redux with less boilerplate.

docs.title: Install:
docs.text: npm install @reduxjs/toolkit react-redux

docs.title: Create a Slice
docs.text:
import { createSlice, configureStore } from "@reduxjs/toolkit";

const counterSlice = createSlice({
  name: "counter",
  initialState: { count: 0 },
  reducers: {
    increment: (state) => {
      state.count += 1;
    },
    decrement: (state) => {
      state.count -= 1;
    },
  },
});

export const { increment, decrement } = counterSlice.actions;
const store = configureStore({ reducer: counterSlice.reducer });
export default store;

docs.title: Use in Component
docs.text:
import { useSelector, useDispatch } from "react-redux";
import { increment, decrement } from "./store";

function Counter() {
  const count = useSelector((state) => state.count);
  const dispatch = useDispatch();

  return (
    <>
      <h1>{count}</h1>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch(increment())}>+</button>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch(decrement())}>-</button>
    </>
  );
}

docs.title: Middleware in Redux
docs.text: Middleware allows handling of side effects (like async API calls).

docs.title: Common Middleware:
docs.text:
• redux-thunk: For asynchronous actions.
  • redux-saga: For complex side effects and background tasks.

docs.title: Example (redux-thunk):
docs.text:
npm install redux-thunk

import { createStore, applyMiddleware } from "redux";
import thunk from "redux-thunk";

const store = createStore(reducer, applyMiddleware(thunk));

const fetchData = () => {
  return async (dispatch) => {
    const response = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data");
    const data = await response.json();
    dispatch({ type: "DATA_LOADED", payload: data });
  };
};

docs.title: Redux DevTools
docs.text:
• A browser extension that lets you inspect actions, state, and changes.
  • Install it and enable it in your store setup:
const store = createStore(
  reducer,
  window.__REDUX_DEVTOOLS_EXTENSION__ && window.__REDUX_DEVTOOLS_EXTENSION__()
);

docs.title: Advantages of Redux
docs.text:
• Predictable state changes
  • Easy debugging and testing
  • Works well with any UI layer (not limited to React)
  • Centralized and consistent data handling

docs.title: Disadvantages of Redux
docs.text:
• Boilerplate code (reduced by Redux Toolkit)
  • Complex setup for small projects
  • Learning curve for beginners

docs.title: When to Use Redux
docs.text:
Use Redux when:

  • You have complex state logic shared across many components.
  • Multiple components need access to the same data.
  • You want predictable and trackable state changes.

Avoid Redux when:

  • The app is small and simple.
  • State can be handled easily using React’s useState or useContext.
